Analyzuj následující text z hlediska stylu, hlasu a tónu. Pomocí NLP vytvoř zadání pro napsání nového článku ve stejném stylu, hlase a tónu:
Energetické úspory ve firmách
Firmy jsou postiženy drahými energiemi stejně jako domácnosti a na jejich ekonomiku to má zásadní dopad. Nejčastěji na zvýšené náklady podniky reagují investicemi do úsporných opatření. Jaká nejčastěji zavádějí a jak tyto změny fungují?
Podle dat ČSÚ se domácnosti v roce 2020 podílely na odběru elektřiny z 28 %. Největší spotřebu zaznamenal energeticky náročný sektor průmyslu (přes 40 %). Ostatní odvětví pak absorbovala necelou třetinu celkové republikové spotřeby (31,6 %). Z dat je zřejmé, že na firmy dopadají drahé energie obzvlášť tíživě. Průzkum Svazu průmyslu a dopravy ze září 2022 navíc ukázal, že jen asi pětina z nich má na rok 2023 zafixované ceny elektřiny a plynu. Na většinu českých podniků proto vysoké náklady na energie zřejmě teprve dopadnou.
Chce-li se firma alespoň částečně zbavit závislosti na nevyzpytatelných tržních cenách energie, nabízí se řešení v podobě vlastní fotovoltaické elektrárny. Tato alespoň částečná soběstačnost pochopitelně láká řadu českých podniků. Na pořízení se podle zmíněného průzkumu Svazu průmyslu a dopravy chystalo téměř 60 % z nich. (Zdroj: PRAM Consulting)
Úspory a vyšší efektivita
V reakci na stoupající výdaje se tak firmy snaží co nejvíce šetřit. Zdaleka nejčastějším opatřením jsou investice do úsporných řešení. „V reakci na vysoké ceny energií jsme provedli hned několik úsporných investic. V první řadě jsme vyměnili starší zdroje elektrických zařízení za jiné, efektivnější. Týkalo se to zejména svítidel, výměna klasických zářivek za nové LED panely nám snížila spotřebu energie na polovinu. Osvětlení jsme proto vyměnili v podstatě všude – ve skladech, v administrativních prostorách i u venkovního osvětlení,“ popisuje Josef Durna, vedoucí správy poboček ze společnosti Gumex, která se zabývá výrobou průmyslových hadic a těsnění či servisem dopravníkových pásů. 
Vyšší efektivita a šetrnost se týkají také samotného provozu. Firmy zvažují, kdy je (a kdy naopak není) nutné svítit a topit, více si hlídají též plýtvání. „Ve skladu a v méně frekventovaných společných prostorách, jako jsou chodby či sociální zařízení, jsme instalovali pohybová čidla. Díky tomu zde svítíme pouze tehdy, když je to skutečně třeba,“ říká Josef Durna. Otázku udržení tepla v místech, kde je to potřeba, mohou podniky vyřešit i speciálními závěsnými fóliemi, které se umisťují do průchodů a vrat. „Toto jednoduché řešení jsme nasadili do všech našich poboček. Pruhové závěsy z měkčeného PVC slouží nejen jako účinný izolant tepla, ale také jako protiprůvanová clona,“ doplňuje Durna. 
„Rostoucí ceny nemůžeme ovlivnit, ale vlastní zdroj elektřiny ano. Proto jsme investovali do fotovoltaické elektrárny o výkonu 50 kW a bateriových úložišť s kapacitou 44 kW. Obojí se chystáme letos na jaře dále rozšířit – elektrárnu až na výkon 80 kW, baterie na kapacitu 77 kW. Díky této investici bychom v době dlouhého denního osvitu dokázali být soběstační ve dne a částečně i v noci. Dokonce existuje varianta, že bychom nespotřebovanou energii prodávali zpět do distribuční sítě,“ vysvětluje Josef Durna a doplňuje: „Potřeba nových investic, růst výroby a výkyvy v dodavatelských cenách způsobují, že je poměrně těžké přesně spočítat úspory, které nám opatření přinesla. Nicméně odhadujeme, že v tuto chvíli ušetříme přibližně 25–30 % elektrické energie ze sítě a s plánovaným rozšířením fotovoltaické elektrárny bude úspora ještě vyšší.“ (Zdroj: PRAM Consulting)

Selling on YouTube is easy with Cafe24

After Facebook, Instagram, and TikTok, the e-commerce ecosystem centered around Cafe24 has now expanded its reach to YouTube. The social media powerhouse, with more than 2.24 billion users as of last year, is now open to showcase and sell products from Cafe24 stores on YouTube.

While any cafe24 customer can already market their brand or products online by posting advertisements on YouTube, the new feature is different in that it allows them to provide product information at the bottom of live broadcasts, pre-produced videos, and uploaded videos, along with a separate category called "Store" for viewers who visit their YouTube channel. This provides an environment for more active communication with viewers, who can be called potential customers, centered on products.

It is more significant that Cafe24 is the first Korean e-commerce platform to introduce this feature after Shopify in the North American market. Let's take a closer look at what Cafe24 shop owners can do on their YouTube channel and the expected effects.

YouTube is making e-commerce easier
"We want to make it easier for creators to connect and manage their own stores on YouTube and offer products directly to their audience."

David Katz, VP of YouTube Shopping Products
Until now, it's been difficult for creators with YouTube channels to showcase and sell products they've created, collaborated with, or outsourced from outside companies. Other than adding a link to their shopping cart in the "more" section at the bottom of their video content or in a sticky comment section for announcements, there's been no way to turn viewers into buyers.
Recognizing this, in July, YouTube began to provide more convenient ways for viewers to see what creators are selling when they visit a YouTube channel. For example, while live broadcasting to interact with viewers on their channel, creators can pin photos, prices, and links to their products to the top of the live chat window.

They can similarly pin product information within the viewing screen of uploaded video content to encourage purchases. It's also worth noting that in the store on their YouTube channel, they've organized the various products they carry into a single catalog, so you can see what they have to offer at a glance.

Viewers = potential customers, viewing and purchasing Cafe24 products on the YouTube channel
Cafe24 has made it possible for you to utilize these features without going into the YouTube settings page, and with just a few clicks from the Cafe24 shop admin page. After completing the necessary settings for the integration through the 'Google Channel' app, which provides Google's advertising and marketing features, you can use the YouTube Shopping feature.

The store category created on the YouTube channel can be updated regularly with product photos, pricing information, and product information in the shopping mall to reflect out-of-stock status, just like Facebook Shops, which Cafe24 currently supports. This is also supported for YouTube Live broadcasts and product information pinned to the bottom of the video.

This allows Cafe24 shop owners to utilize YouTube's social media giant to find new customers and communicate their brand and product information in a more engaging way. Another advantage is that there are no fees for live broadcasts using their own online malls instead of external platforms. From next year, these features will also be available in markets such as Japan and Vietnam, where Cafe24 is present.

Image replacement after the service opens
However, YouTube's current policy requires domestic customers to meet additional requirements, such as having more than 1,000 subscribers, 4,000 hours of public video viewing time in the past year, and a Google Merchant Center account that allows you to import store and product information to Google .

At Cafecafe24, we're proud to be a partner to help our creative customers succeed, and it's great to see our efforts translate into collaborations with a global market leader like YouTube.

The Café24-YouTube collaboration will continue in the future to make e-commerce easy and accessible for both YouTubers and shop owners and their subscribers and potential customers. We'll keep you updated on any further developments.

📚References
Ready, Set, Shop on YouTube
Getting started with YouTube Shopping

En el contexto de un servicio de fisioterapia, en el diseño de una estrategia de precios para ponerle a un programa de tratamiento y seguimiento de 8 a 12 semanas para enfermedad arterial  periférica, ¿Qué atributos valoran en las soluciones que compran los clientes, para satisfacer sus necesidades?
¿Cuál es la importancia de cada atributo en la decisión de compra de este tipo de programas?

DAS


Purpose
The Dynamic Allocation System (DAS) is a resource management tool designed to maximize the efficiency and effectiveness of car park resources such as Time, Space, and Energy. By minimizing waste and optimizing productivity, DAS can help reduce costs and improve operational efficiency. Through a simple booking process, DAS provides an allocation of resources that meets the needs of the user.

 


Scope/Targets
When allocating resources, it is essential to have clear objectives that the system should strive to achieve. These objectives can range from minimizing the number of movements in and out of lanes, reducing the amount of car park space used, and minimizing the number of driver trips, to maximizing efficiency when parking and pulling from lanes, minimizing the distance drivers walk, and reducing the time taken from block park to departures. However, different operations will have different priorities when it comes to these objectives. Therefore, DAS should come with a customizable settings page that allows users to prioritize their targets according to their specific needs. This settings page should be independent per operation as large car parks with few staff will have different requirements than small car parks with many staff. The target must be clear and unambiguous in order for it to be properly implemented. For example, if the target is to reduce driving time between block park and departures, then a prerequisite would be knowing the coordinates of the lanes or car park layout so that an efficient solution can be calculated.
















Requirements
In order for DAS to meet its targets, there are several factors that need to be taken into consideration. The settings page should be used to determine which data is necessary for DAS to function properly on a given dataset. This includes, but is not limited to: 
•	Bookings Return Date
•	Bookings Return Terminal
•	Size of Block Park Area(s)
•	Size of Lanes
•	Size of Departures Area(s)
•	Speciality Area(s) (Valet Zones, EV Zones, Undercover Zones, Extra Long or Extra Wide Vehicles etc.)
•	Locations of Lanes, Entrances & Exits to Block Park and Entrances & Exits to Departures (for calculating distances between Lanes themselves, and lanes to departures)
•	Staff Availability
•	Staff Shift Times
•	Availability of Lanes / Zones (e.g. are Some Zones only available in Summer?)
•	Multi Terminal Lanes
•	How far in advance we are looking for similar arrivals (+ Maximum time before we close & audit a lane)
The system should be customizable in terms of which data sets will be available for DAS to use.

Segments
DAS Segments are a key component of allocation. The system can be configured as either Flexible or Fixed segments. Fixed Segments are a more restrictive approach, where pre-selected times of the day are manually input. The current KMOS segment editor could be expanded to include different segments depending on the day, allowing DAS to function similarly to KMOS without the need for a Key Master. Flexible Segments offer more potential but also more complexity. This approach allows DAS to look ahead at predicted arrivals and departures, combine this data with its targets, and determine its set of segment times per individual day of the year. The more data sets available, the more efficient this approach will be.





















Solution
Once DAS has a set of targets and knows the data sets that will be available at point of allocation you can then configure the algorithm that’ll be used to calculate the final allocation. This is the complex bit so that when you feed DAS a booking (or set of bookings) it follows the algorithm step by step until it produces the allocation.
An example would be something like the below

 


Other factors to consider are Manual Overrides (the ability to allow intervention by a User to change lane allocations). Recalculations (after a day has passed, Non Arrivals / Overstays may mean there is now more or less space available than expected). Unexpected Events; an Incident (e.g. a crash) could cause a temporary lane closure that may affect future allocations for a period. 

Finally DAS should also be periodically reviewed, either manually or by itself to look for improvements. Particularly in the case when there is a limited set of data to begin with. After a period of operation it should be able to detect certain information with greater accuracy (such as weekly trends & seasonal trends). It could then suggest possible changes to the algorithm which if taken into account could lead to more efficiencies.

Overall, DAS is a powerful tool that can be used to automate the allocation of resources in a variety of scenarios. With the right configuration and data sets it can be used to make decisions quickly and accurately, saving time and money.

Carbon emissions trading operates on the basis of the cap-and-trade principle, which sets a cap on the total amount of carbon emissions allowed within a specific period. This cap is then divided into permits that can be traded among companies that emit carbon. Companies that can reduce emissions below the allocated level can sell unused permits to companies that cannot do so, creating a market-based incentive for emissions reductions. Cap-and-trade schemes are designed to create market-driven incentives for companies to invest in green technologies and reduce carbon emissions. In the context of the renewable energy industry, carbon emissions trading can encourage investment in clean energy as companies seek to reduce carbon emissions and obtain licenses for future transactions.
Carbon pricing mechanisms, including carbon trading schemes, can play a key role in attracting private investment in the renewable energy sector, which is critical to meeting global climate goals, according to a World Bank report. The report states that “carbon pricing is an effective tool to guide capital for low-carbon investment, incentivize technological innovation, and help reduce emissions in the most cost-effective manner.” Carbon trading creates opportunities for companies to reduce carbon emissions by allowing them to sell unused allowances. This creates financial incentives, which in turn reduces the overall cost of abatement and promotes more efficient resource allocation.
The success of carbon trading schemes depends on a variety of factors, such as the initial allocation of emission allowances, the stability of carbon prices, and the effectiveness of monitoring and enforcement mechanisms. A study by the International Monetary Fund found that "well-designed carbon pricing systems can help governments generate revenue, encourage private sector investment in clean technologies, and help address climate change in a cost-effective manner." The study also noted that carbon pricing schemes It can help countries meet their climate goals, such as those set out in the Paris Agreement, and foster international cooperation on climate change.

The site's evaluation and selection of external providers were based on documented selection criteria, supply constraints, and testing processes. Non-critical suppliers did not require a quality agreement, and their requirements were communicated through initial communications and necessary documents.

The site established controls for external providers based on the impact of their ability to meet customer requirements. Critical suppliers underwent on-site audits, and incoming inspections were used to establish controls. Supplier performance was monitored and measured through scorecards, and non-conformities were addressed through NCMRs and supplier corrective actions. The audit found documented evidence of management of external providers, including vendor questionnaires, supplier evaluations, and scorecards.

Two external providers, Beaver and Airborne Testing Spider, were reviewed for their compliance status. Beaver had completed their questionnaire and on-site audit without findings, while Airborne Testing Spider was rated as critical and had completed their evaluation form and was ISO certified.

The site made updates and improvements to its supplier management program, including adopting a global procedure and transferring multiple suppliers to the global Approved Supplier List to eliminate redundant on-site audits and better manage suppliers with multiple sites.

Minor issues were identified, such as errors in data entry for a supplier scorecard and inaccuracies in some definitions in the SOP compared to the Global purchasing procedure. The Purchasing and Supply Management SOPs were reviewed and found to need updating to align with SAP and remove unnecessary information.

During the audit, a deviation from the SOP was identified where meeting minutes of the Annual Supplier Review Meeting were not taken as outlined in the procedure. The deviation has been addressed, and corrective action taken to determine if meeting minutes are a requirement and done by other Repligen sites. Additionally, discrepancies were identified in the attachments section of the SOP-033, where they did not align with the section numbering in the SOP.

Overall, the audit found that the Clifton Park site had effective controls and monitoring in place for external providers. The following is the interview response of the beauty brand CEO, Ardman. Please create Instagram content that highlights your achievements based on the information below. Please separate the article into three parts. Suggest suitable titles, emoticons, and hashtags.


1) Brand name meaning
Adman is French. It means see you tomorrow. It means to look forward to new changes with excitement, looking forward to tomorrow as well as today.

2) Start-up opportunity
CEO Kim Yong-hyeok (born in 1990) graduated from the Department of Venture Management at Seoul National University. Since he was in college, he has been interested in entrepreneurship. While working for a company (working at SK Planet in service planning and strategic planning), he thought that it would be impossible to start a business unless it was now, so he quit writing for the company. He first started with a brand business and is now preparing for several businesses.

3) Growth history
In January 2023, skincare brand ‘A’demang’ joined hands with beauty creator ‘Arang’, which has 350,000 subscribers, to conduct ‘live broadcasting (Labang)’ on YouTube. In particular, the 'Arang X Adman Encore 2nd Market' package products, which can only be met during this collaboration period, are organized and introduced, and the purchase certification, review posting events, etc. are held to attract viewers' response, while the chat window in Labang displays purchase certification. and product-related inquiries continued uninterrupted.
In fact, 20,000 viewers flocked to this Labang in one day, and from 7 pm on the day of the broadcast to the next day (29 hours in total), sales exceeded 150 million won, so it was a box office success. This is an achievement achieved in just three weeks after building a D2C (Direct to Consumer) shopping mall.

4) Product/Brand Introduction
Ardman's first product is a toner pad. It was born with the meaning of creating a skin that is expected every day. People need care not only for their skin type but also for their skin condition. Therefore, it was produced with the intention of conditioning the skin that is suitable for oneself by considering the condition of the skin.

5) Product/Brand Differentiation
The difference between toner pads is that they are large, soft in texture, and contain a lot of essence. The larger size was made in response to the opinions of consumers who use toner pads instead of packs. Normally, 2-3 toner pads are used to use as a pack, but one Aardman product is sufficient.

Toner pad and ampoule products have been vegan certified. Both products use Houttuynia cordata ingredients to have soothing and moisturizing effects, and received a green rating from the EWG, an American non-profit environmental research organization, which certifies that they have the lowest harmful ingredients, and were recognized as free from harmful ingredients by the beauty platform Hwahae.

Also, Ardman's cosmetics use a lot of good raw materials even if the cost is high. For example, purified water was not used in the ampoule.

6) Sales (Marketing) Strategy
Collaborate with multiple creators to launch products. The first collaboration was with Arang Creator. In addition, we plan to collaborate with several mega influencers. The reason I work with creators is because they are experts. For example, Arang is the best expert in cosmetics. Arang clearly pointed out what kind of needs there are when developing products and what elements need to be developed to meet those needs.

11) Reasons for choosing Cafe24
After doing online business centered on open markets such as Smart Store and Coupang, they built D2C (own mall) 2-3 weeks ago. The strength of jasamol becomes a real customer when consumers buy. When selling on other platforms, consumers stop buying products, but in D2C, it is possible to provide customized benefits or services according to the customer's inclination. Therefore, it is expected that sales can be increased through D2C.

Design a company, explain the business model, what it sells, how it sells that will help solve the concerns raised by this person:

I'm in the top 2% of users on StackOverflow. My content there has been viewed by over 1.7M people. And it's unlikely I'll ever write anything there again. 

Which may be a much bigger problem than it seems. Because it may be the canary in the mine of our collective knowledge. 

A canary that signals a change in the airflow of knowledge: from human-human via machine, to human-machine only. Don’t pass human, don’t collect 200 virtual internet points along the way.

StackOverflow is *the* repository for programming Q&A. It has 100M users & saves man-years of time & wig-factories-worth of grey hair every single day. 

It is driven by people like me who ask questions that other developers answer. Or vice-versa. Over 10 years I've asked 217 questions & answered 77. Those questions have been read by millions of developers & had tens of millions of views.

But since GPT4 it looks less & less likely any of that will happen; at least for me. Which will be bad for StackOverflow. But if I'm representative of other knowledge-workers then it presents a larger & more alarming problem for us as humans. 

What happens when we stop pooling our knowledge with each other & instead pour it straight into The Machine? Where will our libraries be? How can we avoid total dependency on The Machine? What content do we even feed the next version of The Machine to train on? 

When it comes time to train GPTx it risks drinking from a dry riverbed. Because programmers won't be asking many questions on StackOverflow. GPT4 will have answered them in private. So while GPT4 was trained on all of the questions asked before 2021 what will GPT6 train on? 

This raises a more profound question. If this pattern replicates elsewhere & the direction of our collective knowledge alters from outward to humanity to inward into the machine then we are dependent on it in a way that supercedes all of our prior machine-dependencies. 

Whether or not it "wants" to take over, the change in the nature of where information goes will mean that it takes over by default. 

Like a fast-growing Covid variant, AI will become the dominant source of knowledge simply by virtue of growth. If we take the example of StackOverflow, that pool of human knowledge that used to belong to us - may be reduced down to a mere weighting inside the transformer. 

Or, perhaps even more alarmingly, if we trust that the current GPT doesn't learn from its inputs, it may be lost altogether. Because if it doesn't remember what we talk about & we don't share it then where does the knowledge even go?

We already have an irreversible dependency on machines to store our knowledge. But at least we control it. We can extract it, duplicate it, go & store it in a vault in the Arctic (as Github has done). 

So what happens next? I don't know, I only have questions. 

None of which you'll find on StackOverflow.

2. Team and Organizational Update 

 
The past few months were challenging as we spent an unexpected amount of time fixing breakages in unfamiliar systems and felt the loss of our departed colleagues. Despite these difficulties, we successfully delivered on our business goals achieving +16.88% iOPS vs OP2, +35.11% net CCP vs OP2. For OP2, we focused on the LP “invent and simplify” to maintain customer obsession as we rebuilt our roadmap. We pooled engineering resources between Paid and Earned to avoid being constrained by preassigned org structure, and selected initiatives that were best for Amazon across both teams. Rather than just drawing a new cutline based on fewer resources (which could have significantly reduced morale), we analyzed each initiative line-by-line and task-by-task, exploring creative solutions with partner teams to combine forces or make ownership adjustments to pick up items falling BTL.

 

One highlight is our collaboration with Social that leverages their loaned headcount to provide TMT customers off-Amazon with the best offerings and most accurate representation of Amazon’s catalog through Data Subscription Service. This service improves the fidelity and accuracy of ASIN attribute data while making access to core advertising product attributes easy for new opportunities to experiment and launch.  

 

The new roadmap led to the reallocation of projects and the shifting of SDEs. For instance, the CN engineering team expanded their scope from supporting only the SEO pipeline to owning Paid initiatives and the Experimentation systems. While the overall PM/engineering management structure remains unchanged, several engineering teams have adopted new charters that will continue to be relevant in the years ahead. 

 

Despite these improvements, only 22% of our roadmap is dedicated to growth initiatives with 33% of our engineering resources allocated to KTLO and 45% allocated to OE. It was disappointing to cut $389 MM net CCP in projects with approved specs and dedicated owners, but through this process we remained focused on creative problem solving, earned trust, and grew closer as a team. 


4. 2023 Overview 

 
In 2023, we remain dedicated to investing in our long-term vision as outlined in our 3YP. We started with the most business critical projects when drafting our roadmap causing 78% of our engineering resources to be largely dedicated to objective two of our 3YP: “Minimize overhead while developing flexible, resilient software architecture that supports Search Marketing.” These technical investments are 33% KTLO and 45% OE, with our OE initiatives deemed essential re-architecture efforts to reduce the cost to serve and streamline initiatives. Several of our engineering projects nearly pay themselves off in the first year of effort: Project Kondo’s 2023 investment costs 15 eng weeks, but saves us 33 weeks of legacy upkeep and with additional work next year, it is expected to unlock $290M CCP in three years. In addition, Search Marketing Toolkit’s Hydra Migration costs us 70 weeks, but saves 30 weeks in year one and 110 weeks by year three. 

 

Following these must-have investments, the remaining 22% of our roadmap is allocated to ensuring investment in our critical projects, such as Marketing Context Service (MCS) and the integration of Optimal Inventory Health (OIH) signals into our bidder. Through repeated emphasis on invent and simplify, we continue to have the ability to invest in other critical areas of our 3YP such as Experimentation and Profitability, and we are looking for creative solutions to continue progress in BTL items (accounting for $389M CCP) by utilizing an away-team model.

I have a company founded in colombia on march 2022. In the begining there were 3 co-founders and i payed in october 2022 an amount that was equivalent to 25% of the company. The company is named Celes. Celes is a SaaS B2B that connects to an ERP, analyzes the data and gives recommendations about what to purchases and when, besides, it provides helpful business intelligence reports and customer segmentation. Celes serves companies in the retail sector that benefit from this services as they can have lower stocks and a lower expectation of lost sales. 
The company has been growing and currently we have 30.000 USD in MRR, an average 1000 USD revenue per client, 12 employees, we pay low salaries compared to the industry and we are not burning money (the incompe received is enough to pay for our current costs of servers, admin and payroll).
We are raising money to accelerate our growth and to increase the value provided by our product by hiring more developers, Technical Account Managers and Data Engineers. We expecto to raise $800.000 USD via SAFE from angles and institutional investors with a pre-money cap of $6.0000.000 USD. All this money will be received by a new c-corp company established in Delaware, US.
We contacted a company in ireland named Primeline that is a provider to 100% of the biggest retailers in ireland and have a very close relationship with them. They love our product and became a customer of their own.
Primeline proposed to invest 300.000 USD via SAFE on the terms that we are raising and were previously exposed. FOr this investment they are asking for a seat in oour board. Apart from that, we are working in a deal where we create a Joint Venture established in ireland called Primalytics. The owners of this Joint Venture will be Primeline (50%) AND Celes Delaware (50%). The purpose of this Joint Venture is to be the official seller of Celes in ireland where Celes Delaware provides the product and everything involved and Primeline will contact its clients so that they purchase Celes services via this JV.
The initial proposal was that the 2 companies would split the net revenue of this JV (Revenue after admin and fiscal costs are covered). I think that this deal is advantageous for primeline given that Celes will do all the work and Primeline has nothing to lose from this partnership but the average client in ireland would be at least 4.000 USD, which would provide a nice additional source of revenue for us even when we have to give 50% of the revenue for those deals and also would make the company more valueable given that the product would be proven to work in europe with big brands.
Now primeline is proposing this:

"Primeline commits to Investment USD 300k into the Celes Delaware investment company directly. This investment to be returned to the Primalytics JV in Ireland to fund a sales and marketing team focused on growing ARR from EMEA. This represents 5% share in the business and would come with a board seat focused on growing the business.
We confirm a vesting vehicle that allows for 50% of the ARR generated out of the Primalytics JV to convert to Equity in Celes based on a 15 times ARR multiple. If Celes is sold for 20 times multiple Primeline’s 50% share of JV sales would convert at 15 times. If Celes is sold at below 15 times then Primeline would match the lower than 15 times multiple for conversion to shares.
We believe the focus on selling Celes in Europe and EMEA through the Irish JV will drive significant ARR value quickly.
We believe our extensive network into retailers and brands uniquely positions us to drive Celes ARR to USD 1m plus from EMEA."

I dont think this is fair because i understand that they will increase the value of their 300kUSD investment inn Celes Delawere when the company sells more and additionally, each dollar sold in Ireland would give them more and more participation in the company. I might be wrong but i think this will give them a double winning while we are the ones doing all the work.

The co-founder leading the negotiation is proposing this:

"50% of the revenue from the JV, will be converted to equity at the series A valuation with a 20% discount. That would be like making a SAFE with a cap and discount that is typical from YCombinator".

I think it might be a sound counter proposal but i am not sure if it would give primeline an over advantageous benefit compared to standard or commom practices in this regard. I would very much like to have the JV with them because it would increase our revenue and the valuation of the company. I think Primeline is fundamental to enter that market. My way to defend this proposal is thinking we will receive capital in the way of the revenue that would otherwise go to Primeline and we will use that money before the series A, so giving additional equity for that money could be fair and the discount will recognize the decrease in value of that money at the time of the series A.

Please provide a proposal that will make primeline and me very confortable given the context provided. Please ask as many questions as you need about what you need to know to provide a comprehensive answer.

Microsoft wil 10 miljard dollar betalen voor 49 procent van ChatGPT-maker'
Microsoft zou 10 miljard dollar willen investeren in ChatGPT-maker OpenAI en zou 49 procent van diens aandelen willen. De investering zou gepaard gaan met andere investeerders, die eveneens 49 procent van OpenAI in handen zouden krijgen.

OpenAI en Microsoft zijn volgens Semafor-bronnen de afgelopen weken in gesprek geweest over de investering, waarbij Microsoft 75 procent van OpenAI's winst zou krijgen tot het bedrijf zijn investering terug heeft verdiend. Daarna zou Microsoft 49 procent van OpenAI in handen hebben en andere investeerders 49 procent. Een non-profit zou dan de resterende 2 procent van OpenAI houden.

Met de investering zou OpenAI gewaardeerd worden op 29 miljard dollar. Eerder zeiden Wall Street Journal-bronnen al dat investeringsbedrijven Thrive Capital en Founders Fund interesse hadden in een deel van OpenAI, waarbij eveneens een waardering van 29 miljard dollar werd genoemd. Die krant schreef in oktober al dat Microsoft in gesprek was om een groter deel van OpenAI in handen te kunnen krijgen.

Microsoft en OpenAI zijn geen onbekenden van elkaar: in 2019 investeerde het bedrijf al een miljard dollar in OpenAI. Daarnaast zeiden The Information-bronnen onlangs dat Microsoft ChatGPT wil integreren in Word, PowerPoint, Outlook en Bing. Microsoft en OpenAI wilden niet reageren op de deal. OpenAI bracht in november een publieke versie uit van AI-gesprekstool ChatGPT.  SI dit een goede deal voor Microsoft?Het is moeilijk om te zeggen of dit een goede deal voor Microsoft is zonder meer informatie te hebben over de specifieke details van de deal.
Maar als we algemene kijk op de situatie nemen:OpenAI is een bedrijf dat zich richt op onderzoek en ontwikkeling van kunstmatige intelligentie (AI) en heeft een aantal toonaangevende technologieën zoals GPT-3 (de ChatGPT-maker genoemd in de bericht)Microsoft heeft al eerder geïnvesteerd in OpenAI en heeft kennis van het bedrijf, dus het is waarschijnlijk dat ze vertrouwd zijn met de waardevoorstelling van OpenAI.Een investering van $10 miljard voor 49% van het bedrijf, zou een waardering van $20 miljard dollar voor OpenAI weergeven. Dit is redelijk significant bedrag voor een bedrijf dat zich richt op AI-onderzoek, en zou aangeven dat Microsoft de waarde van de technologieën van OpenAI inziet.Daarom, als Microsoft in staat is om de technologieën van OpenAI efficiënt te integreren in hun bestaande producten en oplossingen, en er een goed rendement op hun investering komt, zou het kunnen zijn een goede deal voor hen.Het is belangrijk te realiseren dat dit slechts geruchten zijn en er geen officiële bevestiging is van het bericht. Beide bedrijven hebben geweigerd om te reageren.GPT-3 maaklt gebruik van Microsoft Azure SaaS en ChatGPT cponsumeert nu per dag 3 miljoed dollar. Wat vindt je daarvan Het feit dat GPT-3 maakt gebruik van Microsoft Azure SaaS, suggereert dat er een nauwe samenwerking bestaat tussen OpenAI en Microsoft, en dat Microsofts cloud-oplossing een belangrijk onderdeel is van hoe GPT-3 wordt gehost en geleverd.Het consumptiebedrag van 3 miljoen dollar per dag voor ChatGPT, suggereert dat er een groot volume aan verzoeken is naar de service, en dat ChatGPT een populaire en waardevolle aanvulling is op het productaanbod van OpenAI. Het feit dat ChatGPT zo'n hoog kostenbedrag heeft, kan ook suggereren dat er een hoge vraag naar de service is van zakelijke klanten en dat de service waarschijnlijk een aantrekkelijke inkomstenbron is voor OpenAI.Als het bedrijf Microsoft 49% van OpenAI zou verkrijgen, zou dit een grote boost betekenen voor OpenAI, in termen van financiering, technologie en marktbereik, dit zou betekenen dat de technologieën van OpenAI zullen kunnen worden geïntegreerd in de producten en oplossingen van Microsoft, waardoor de aantrekkingskracht van de service vergroot zal worden voor nog meer bedrijven.Echter, het is belangrijk om te realiseren dat het consumptiebedrag van 3 miljoen dollar per dag voor ChatGPT slechts geruchten zijn, zonder officiële bevestiging is het lastig om te zeggen of dit daadwerkelijk het geval is.de gebruikerc van ChatGPT betalen nu in de meeste gevallen (nog) niets.Het is inderdaad waarschijnlijk dat de meeste gebruikers van ChatGPT op dit moment geen directe kosten betalen voor de service. Dit komt omdat OpenAI ChatGPT momenteel aanbiedt als een "open access" service, waarbij iedereen gratis toegang heeft tot de technologie. Dit is een gebruikelijke manier waarop AI-bedrijven hun technologieën ontwikkelen en testen, voordat ze commercieel beschikbaar zijn gemaakt.Echter, als de veronderstelling waar is dat ChatGPT nu per dag 3 miljoen dollar kost, is het goed mogelijk dat OpenAI plannen heeft om de technologie commercieel beschikbaar te maken en inkomsten te genereren uit de service. Dit kan bijvoorbeeld door middel van prijsmodellen voor hogere volumes aan verzoeken of specifieke functies, of door middel van enterprise licenties voor bedrijven die de technologie willen integreren in hun eigen producten of oplossingen.Het is belangrijk om te realiseren dat dit allemaal speculatie is, gebaseerd op geruchten en zonder officiële bevestiging van OpenAI over hun plannen voor ChatGPT. OpenAI zou zich hierover willen uitlaten als ze dat willen.

necesito que actues como un ejecutivo de una empresa
me vas a ayudar a construir el contenido por cada slide de una presentación que debemos preparar para un cliente 

Yo te daré el contexto de la presentación en cuanto al tema que se va a tratar, antecedentes y la solución planteada

quisiera recibir un planteamiento de cómo separar el contenido por láminas, cuántas láminas recomiendas y el texto a colocar en cada una basado en la información provista. Yo me encargaré de la parte de diseño, imagen y gráficos a colocar en cada una. Igualmente si puedes tener sugerencias de la parte gráfica/visual, te lo agradezco

A continuación la información:

Contexto
El servicio que se presta es para un programa constantemente cambiante que requiere adaptaciones recurrentes. Han sucedido cambios en la dirección del programa dentro del cliente, lo que se presta para confusiones en el entendimiento de la cronología de la base de datos actual. para las que debemos establecer en conjunto una metodología acorde con esta condición, a fin de poder garantizar el correcto funcionamiento, tanto operativo, como del manejo de los registros y los datos que conforman la base.

Antecedentes
Información sobre campos y criterios de registro no fue claro desde el inicio.

Lo mismo ocurría con cada campo que se fue adicionando en el tiempo.

También ocurría esta situación para nuevas patologías, pruebas o tipos de muestra que se incluían operativamente pero no se recibía la información correspondiente de los criterios de registro que requería el cliente.

Existe unos datos dentro de la base que fueron proporcionados por el cliente y que contienen una gran cantidad de datos vacíos que el cliente señala como errores, los cuales no son atribuibles a la gestión de TBTB. Éstos campos vacíos los podemos adecuar a fin de brindar una capacidad de análisis adecuada para el negocio, sin embargo, debemos tener la aprobación del cliente en cuanto a la adaptación propuesta.

El software que utilizamos para el registro de la operación tiene ciertas limitaciones que nos han llevado a implementar herramientas externas de control para evitar errores de digitación o de algoritmo.

Esta situación no nos ocurre con los programas donde tenemos claridad de la información a registrar y el manejo de la base de datos que requiere el cliente, y si se identifican errores son mínimos en volumen y de muy fácil corrección.

Podemos demostrar con productos reales otros programas donde somos los administradores de la bases de datos y de la operación en E2E y donde adicionalmente, generamos servicios de Dashboards e Indicadores del negocio y operativos 


Solución
Inicialmente es necesario alinear con el cliente la situación general de la data en la base, para que conozcan el historial de cada campo, las condiciones actuales de registro en cada uno, fechas de inicio de registros en los mismos, entre otros. Para esto, presentaremos el Inventario de Data en la base a fin de poner en su conocimiento esta información e iniciar las actividades de alineamiento para estandarización de los campos que lo requieran.

Ejecutar las correcciones necesarias en la base de datos actual, luego de la alineación con el cliente y en común acuerdo con las soluciones definidas para cada caso, al igual que el cronograma de tiempo de dichas soluciones.

Implementar el uso del AdminCentral, un software especializado en operaciones de diagnóstico y seguimiento a pacientes que hemos desarrollado en TBTB que nos permitirá crear los algoritmos, listas, restricciones, campos obligatorios, entre otros,  para asegurar la calidad y confiabilidad de los registros que necesita el programa.

Please compose a pitch deck of eight to fifteen slides for my company, Cortado, based on the following outline:
************************Intro / Hook************************

My name is [ FNAME ], and over the last X months my partner and I took a real estate company from launch to more than $350,000 in revenue by leveraging new AI tools to target an $71 trillion niche housing market.

How have we taken Cortado to this point? We utilized a tried-and-true rental arbitrage model to  target a deeply undersupplied housing market, while leveraging a suite of AI-powered tools to quickly scale our MVP; acquiring, marketing and managing all Cortado inventory without a single new hire.

- In 10 months, we’ve taken Cortado from $0 to $350,000 in revenue by leveraging low-cost AI tools to target a massive niche housing market: international student housing.

**********************Market Size**********************

What is this niche market? International student housing, an undersupplied subset of the growing MTR market.

- 6+ million students per year (8m by 2025)
- 5.5% growth over the last 20 years, even through COVID (4.28% growth from 2019-2020)
- Total Available Market (TAM) of $71 trillion
    - $214 per week average ([source](https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/1cwVYQgmUBjj_FjMlpHg4Ru01K7bRY_Bq))
    - 6,361,963 international students in 2020 ([source](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ft1EJsDua-FjUPVw-gegaX5t6coQVYzz9ghe6wNGVZ8/edit#gid=1422332990))
        - TAM = ((weekly avg/7)*365)*#int’l students
    - Doesn’t include domestic exchange or additional MTR verticals (traveling nurses, digital nomads)

**********************************************Why target this market? (i.e. the problem)**********************************************

So why international student housing? It’s a mouthful and, I’ll be the first to admit, “student housing” isn’t the sexiest market out there. And for that very reason, this niche housing market has flown under the radar of VCs, angel groups and other startups.

Imagine arriving in a new city for work or study; you need a move-in ready stay, yet you can’t afford a hotel and aren’t sure what the best (or even safe) neighborhoods are.

- The traditional rental long-term rental market can’t serve you; you’re only here for 3 or 4 months, and don’t have time to pick out furniture
    - Plus, you may not even have the credit score or guarantor needed to sign a lease
- Hotels & vacation rentals are way out of your price range
- Traditional student housing, if there is any, has already been snapped up by full-time students

As a result, you’re left between a sketchy Craigslist sublet halfway across town or crashing at a youth hostel until you can figure something better out (as founder Perry did while studying abroad in Barcelona).

************************************************So what’s the solution?************************************************

This market needs affordable, flexible, (trusted?) move-in ready housing near their place of work or study, often in the world’s toughest real estate markets.

********************************Cortado’s Model********************************

Cortado’s model meets and exceeds these criteria, while generating outsized returns.

1. Partner with local homeowners to quickly source new inventory
2. Furnish and photograph the home in under 48 hours
3. Market the home by-the-room with tiered “smart pricing” to provide an affordable, community-centered living experience to our guests (and peace of mind to their parents and universities), while maintaining a target revenue occupancy of 90-95%

********************************************************************************How profitable is this model? (traction)********************************************************************************

To date, Cortado has generate over $350,000 in gross revenue, and returns of XX% across 9 rental properties in Washington, DC.

- Our new housing now comes almost exclusively from homeowner referrals, showing supply-side traction for our master lease model
- Demand, we were able to book all rooms for spring 2023 with $0 ad spend
- Summer 2022 we booked out within 10 days
- Programs such as Stanford, Atlantis, &c &c reach out to us on a regular basis (not enough rooms)

We project with just XX% of global market share, we could achieve an exit valuation of $XB

**************************************How do we scale operations?**************************************

The key with any rental arbitrage business is margins; keep costs low and revenue high while scaling quickly & sustainably. It’s a tricky balance to strike, and plenty of companies have burned to the ground trying to make it work.

******************************Increasing Margins****************************** - After base rent and furniture, our biggest expense moving forward will be people, marketing & software, costs that can be greatly reduced by leveraging and customizing AI tools just now hitting the market:

-

- Cortado has already achieved a first-mover effect in Washington, DC, one of the country’s most-competitive real estate markets
    - We can quickly replicate this in other domestic and especially foreign markets through B2B relationships and low-cost marketing outreach
    - Although the barrier to entry to this market is low, brand recognition is incredibly important with slow-moving academic institutions like Stanford or Brown

Create a perfect headline title about these articles  OpenAI launches ChatGPT API for businesses at competitive price OpenAI has made its API for ChatGPT generally available, based on a cheaper model that allows developers to easily call on the powerful generative AI for in-app usage.

ChatGPT API accesses a model known as ‘GPT-3.5 turbo’, the same used for the ChatGPT web product. Developers can easily interact with it via a simple endpoint and use it for any of the tasks that ChatGPT is capable of undertaking, from within their website or application.

Leaning on its agreement with Microsoft, the model runs on Azure compute infrastructure which connects to user endpoints. This allows it to run independently of server load on the ChatGPT website, offering businesses a dedicated lane for AI processing.

The API will cost firms $0.002 (£0.0017) per 1,000 tokens, a value worth around 750 words, a sum 10 times smaller than other GPT-3.5 models.

OpenAI stated that this was made possible by a 90% cost reduction in ChatGPT since December, without going into details on how this was achieved. 
Enterprise customers seeking reliable access to the model can also purchase dedicated instances, in an agreement in which OpenAI will allocate Azure compute infrastructure solely for the customers’ use.

OpenAI has stated that this arrangement may be the most economical for developers expecting requests in excess of 450 million tokens per day, and can be agreed via direct contact with the company.
OpenAI admitted that it has not met its own targets for delivering a stable service since December, but that it is committed to achieving this over time.
“For the past two months our uptime has not met our own expectations nor that of our users,” read the blog post.

“Our engineering team’s top priority is now stability of production use cases - we know that ensuring AI benefits all of humanity requires being a reliable service provider. Please hold us accountable for improved uptime over the upcoming months!”

Data processed through the API is not used for model training or other improvements to its service unless the organisation chooses to opt-in, and OpenAI has shelved its ‘pre-launch review’ policy which had required developers to flag what they used the model for before it could be integrated within their app.

“Data submitted to the OpenAI API is not used for training, and we have a new 30-day retention policy and are open to less on a case-by-case basis,” tweeted Sam Altman, CEO at OpenAI.
“For the past two months our uptime has not met our own expectations nor that of our users,” read the blog post.

“Our engineering team’s top priority is now stability of production use cases - we know that ensuring AI benefits all of humanity requires being a reliable service provider. Please hold us accountable for improved uptime over the upcoming months!”

Data processed through the API is not used for model training or other improvements to its service unless the organisation chooses to opt-in, and OpenAI has shelved its ‘pre-launch review’ policy which had required developers to flag what they used the model for before it could be integrated within their app.

“Data submitted to the OpenAI API is not used for training, and we have a new 30-day retention policy and are open to less on a case-by-case basis,” tweeted Sam Altman, CEO at OpenAI.
We've also removed our pre-launch review and made our terms of service and usage policies more developer-friendly.”

The latest model, gpt-3.5-turbo-0301, will be supported until June and a new stable release of the gpt-3.5-turbo is expected in April.

Developers will be given the choice to adopt stable models or specific models according to their needs.

Popular apps that have already made use of the ChatGPT API include Shop, the commerce app by Shopify, which has implemented ChatGPT API to provide more accurate in-app searches and personalised product suggestions for users.
Whisper, OpenAI’s speech recognition system launched in September 2022, was also made available via API at $0.006 (£0.005) per minute of transcribed audio. The open-source model is capable of both transcribing audio and translating speech into English, and can process a number of common audio and video file types.

Through the API, developers can leverage the new ‘large-v2’ model for Whisper which brings speed and quality improvements to its output.

The API offering represents another step towards the full monetisation of ChatGPT, a vital task in the wake of reports that OpenAI’s models are too expensive to run without sizeable income. Altman himself described the firm’s costs as “eye-watering” in December 2022.

Much of this funding may have now been secured through Microsoft’s $10 billion investment in OpenAI, which cemented the dominance of both firms within the AI market. ChatGPT has an ever-expanding presence on Azure and the Redmond giant’s decision to integrate GPT-3.5 into Bing and Edge puts it on competitive footing against Google.

Separate from its influential investors, February saw OpenAI launch its paid tier ChatGPT Plus in the US, offering subscribers faster response times, stable access, and priority updates for $20 (£16) per month.

Some have questioned the cost of ChatGPT Plus in the wake of the API announcement, particularly given that the API allows access to the GPT-3.5 large language model (LLM) at a fraction of that price.

“I hope this pricing impacts ChatGPT+,” wrote a user on the Y Combinator forums.

“$20 is equivalent to what, 10,000,000 tokens? At ~750 words/1k tokens, that’s 7.5 million words per month, or roughly 250,000 words per day, 10,416 words per hour, 173 words per minute, every minute, 24/7. I do not have that big of a utilisation need. It’s kind of weird to vastly overpay.”

To call ChatGPT, the free text-generating AI developed by San Francisco-based startup OpenAI, a hit is a massive understatement.

As of December, ChatGPT had an estimated more than 100 million monthly active users. It’s attracted major media attention and spawned countless memes on social media. It’s been used to write hundreds of e-books in Amazon’s Kindle store. And it’s credited with co-authoring at least one scientific paper.

But OpenAI, being a business — albeit a capped-profit one — had to monetize ChatGPT somehow, lest investors get antsy. It took a step toward this with the launch of a premium service, ChatGPT Plus, in February. And it made a bigger move today, introducing an API that’ll allow any business to build ChatGPT tech into their apps, websites, products and services.


An API was always the plan. That’s according to Greg Brockman, the president and chairman of OpenAI (and also one of the co-founders). He spoke with me yesterday afternoon via a video call ahead of the launch of the ChatGPT API.

“It takes us a while to get these APIs to a certain quality level,” Brockman said. “I think it’s kind of this, like, just being able to meet the demand and the scale.”

Brockman says the ChatGPT API is powered by the same AI model behind OpenAI’s wildly popular ChatGPT, dubbed “gpt-3.5-turbo.” GPT-3.5 is the most powerful text-generating model OpenAI offers today through its API suite; the “turbo” moniker refers to an optimized, more responsive version of GPT-3.5 that OpenAI’s been quietly testing for ChatGPT.

Priced at $0.002 per 1,000 tokens, or about 750 words, Brockman claims that the API can drive a range of experiences, including “non-chat” applications. Snap, Quizlet, Instacart and Shopify are among the early adopters.

The initial motivation behind developing gpt-3.5-turbo might’ve been to cut down on ChatGPT’s gargantuan compute costs. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman once called ChatGPT’s expenses “eye-watering,” estimating them at a few cents per chat in compute costs. (With over a million users, that presumably adds up quickly.)


But Brockman says that gpt-3.5-turbo is improved in other ways.

“If you’re building an AI-powered tutor, you never want the tutor to just give an answer to the student. You want it to always explain it and help them learn — that’s an example of the kind of system you should be able to build [with the API],” Brockman said. “We think this is going to be something that will just, like, make the API much more usable and accessible.”

The ChatGPT API underpins My AI, Snap’s recently announced chatbot for Snapchat+ subscribers, and Quizlet’s new Q-Chat virtual tutor feature. Shopify used the ChatGPT API to build a personalized assistant for shopping recommendations, while Instacart leveraged it to create Ask Instacart, an upcoming toll that’ll allow Instacart customers to ask about food and get “shoppable” answers informed by product data from the company’s retail partners.

“Grocery shopping can require a big mental load, with a lot of factors at play, like budget, health and nutrition, personal tastes, seasonality, culinary skills, prep time, and recipe inspiration,” Instacart chief architect JJ Zhuang told me via email. “What if AI could take on that mental load, and we could help the household leaders who are commonly responsible for grocery shopping, meal planning, and putting food on the table — and actually make grocery shopping truly fun? Instacart’s AI system, when integrated with OpenAI’s ChatGPT, will enable us to do exactly that, and we’re thrilled to start experimenting with what’s possible in the Instacart app.”

Those who’ve been closely following the ChatGPT saga, though, might be wondering if it’s ripe for release — and rightly so.


Early on, users were able to prompt ChatGPT to answer questions in racist and sexist ways, a reflection of the biased data on which ChatGPT was initially trained. (ChatGPT’s training data includes a broad swath of internet content, namely e-books, Reddit posts and Wikipedia articles.) ChatGPT also invents facts without disclosing that it’s doing so, a phenomenon in AI known as hallucination.

ChatGPT — and systems like it — are susceptible to prompt-based attacks as well, or malicious adversarial prompts that get them to perform tasks that weren’t a part of their original objectives. Entire communities on Reddit have formed around finding ways to “jailbreak” ChatGPT and bypass any safeguards that OpenAI put in place. In one of the less offensive examples, a staffer at startup Scale AI was able to get ChatGPT to divulge information about its inner technical workings.

Brands, no doubt, wouldn’t want to be caught in the crosshairs. Brockman is adamant they won’t be. Why so? One reason, he says, is continued improvements on the back end — in some cases at the expense of Kenyan contract workers. But Brockman emphasized a new (and decidedly less controversial) approach that OpenAI calls Chat Markup Language, or ChatML. ChatML feeds text to the ChatGPT API as a sequence of messages together with metadata. That’s as opposed to the standard ChatGPT, which consumes raw text represented as a series of tokens. (The word “fantastic” would be split into the tokens “fan,” “tas” and “tic,” for example.)

For example, given the prompt “What are some interesting party ideas for my 30th birthday?” a developer can choose to append that prompt with an additional prompt like “You are a fun conversational chatbot designed to help users with the questions they ask. You should answer truthfully and in a fun way!” or “You are a bot” before having the ChatGPT API process it. These instructions help to better tailor — and filter — the ChatGPT model’s responses, according to Brockman.


“We’re moving to a higher-level API. If you have a more structured way of representing input to the system, where you say, ‘this is from the developer’ or ‘this is from the user’ … I should expect that, as a developer, you actually can be more robust [using ChatML] against these kinds of prompt attacks,” Brockman said.

Another change that’ll (hopefully) prevent unintended ChatGPT behavior is more frequent model updates. With the release of gpt-3.5-turbo, developers will by default be automatically upgraded to OpenAI’s latest stable model, Brockman says, starting with gpt-3.5-turbo-0301 (released today). Developers will have the option to remain with an older model if they so choose, though, which might somewhat negate the benefit.

Whether they opt to update to the newest model or not, Brockman notes that some customers — mainly large enterprises with correspondingly large budgets — will have deeper control over system performance with the introduction of dedicated capacity plans. First detailed in documentation leaked earlier this month, OpenAI’s dedicated capacity plans, launched today, let customers pay for an allocation of compute infrastructure to run an OpenAI model — for example, gpt-3.5-turbo. (It’s Azure on the back end, by the way.)

In addition to “full control” over the instance’s load — normally, calls to the OpenAI API happen on shared compute resources — dedicated capacity gives customers the ability to enable features such as longer context limits. Context limits refer to the text that the model considers before generating additional text; longer context limits allow the model to “remember” more text essentially. While higher context limits might not solve all the bias and toxicity issues, they could lead models like gpt-3.5-turbo to hallucinate less.


Brockman says that dedicated capacity customers can expect gpt-3.5-turbo models with up to a 16k context window, meaning they can take in four times as many tokens as the standard ChatGPT model. That might let someone paste in pages and pages of tax code and get reasonable answers from the model, say — a feat that’s not possible today.

Brockman alluded to a general release in the future, but not anytime soon.

“The context windows are starting to creep up, and part of the reason that we’re dedicated-capacity-customers-only right now is because there’s a lot of performance tradeoffs on our side,” Brockman said. “We might eventually be able to offer an on-demand version of the same thing.”

Given OpenAI’s increasing pressure to turn a profit after a multibillion-dollar investment from Microsoft, that wouldn’t be terribly surprising.

Pros and Cons of Special Purpose Vehicles
What It Means for Individual Investors

A special purpose vehicle (SPV) is a legal entity created by the parent company but managed as a separate organization.

Key Takeaways
A special purpose vehicle (SPV) is a subsidiary legal entity created by a parent company to isolate the financial risk of certain assets, projects, or ventures.

SPVs have their own assets, liabilities, and financial statements. The assets held within an SPV do not appear on the balance sheet of the parent company.

SPVs are also special purpose entities (SPEs) and are considered off balance sheet vehicles (OBSVs).
SPVs have unique tax benefits, are easy to set up, help manage risk, and have very few regulation requirements.
They can also be risky investments and hurt the parent company’s reputation should the assets perform poorly.
Definition and Examples of Special Purpose Vehicles
A special purpose vehicle (SPV), also referred to as a special purpose entity (SPE), is a separate entity created by a parent organization to isolate certain financial risks.1 An SPV is a subsidiary legal structure that has its own assets and liabilities. It is an asset that is not shown on the balance sheet of the parent company.

Alternate names: off-balance sheet vehicle (OBSV), special purpose entity
SPVs can be created using different legal structures, such as a limited liability company (LLC), a trust, a limited partnership, or a corporation.

The sole purpose of an SPV is to separate the risk of the ventures in the SPV from the parent company’s operations. The parent company makes the business decisions, not the SPV, which is governed by rules clearly defined upon the entity’s creation.

A company might create an SPV to separate the financial risks associated with a product or department so that the parent company isn’t damaged financially.

For example, banks often convert pools of mortgages into SPVs and sell them to investors to separate the investment risk and spread it among many investors. Another example of why a company might create an SPV is to create a lease that can be expensed on its income statement rather than being a liability on its balance sheet.

How Special Purpose Vehicles Work
A parent company may have projects or assets it would like to keep off its balance sheets to avoid the financial risks these assets may impose on the parent company. To do so, it can create an SPV to isolate the assets and securitize them by selling shares to investors.

Note
The parent company will create an SPV so it can sell assets on its balance sheet to the SPV and obtain financing for the subsidiary projects.

Depending on the subsidiary project, the parent company may choose to create an SPV with one of the following legal entity structures:

Limited Partnership (LP)
Limited Liability Company (LLC)
Trust
Corporation
Once the SPV has been created, it obtains funds to purchase the assets from the parent company via debt financing and seeking investments from individual equity investors. Since the SPV now owns the assets, those assets become the collateral for the securities issued.

As a result, investors and lenders can evaluate the company by the quality of the collateral rather than the creditworthiness of the parent company, allowing for the potential for lower financing costs.

Some of the most common reasons behind why a company may create an SPV include:

Securitization: SPVs are often used to securitize loans and receivables.
Asset transfer: Some assets are difficult or impossible to transfer. Companies create SPVs to own a single asset or multiple assets by selling the asset to the SPV.
Financing: SPVs are a popular way to secure funding for a new venture without directly affecting the parent company’s financials.
Raising capital: SPVs may be able to raise capital at more favorable rates as opposed to the parent company raising money.
SPVs do not have independent management or employees and are instead administered by a trustee that follows defined rules to manage the assets. Furthermore, they are structured in such a way that they cannot go bankrupt in practice.

Pros and Cons of Special Purpose Vehicles
Pros
Special tax benefits

Spread the risk among many investors

Easy to set up

Corporations can isolate risks from the parent company

Cons
Lack of transparency

Lack of regulation

Reputational risk to the parent company

Liquidity risks

Pros Explained
Special tax benefits: Some assets of SPVs are exempt from direct taxes if they are established in specific geographical locations, such as the Cayman Islands.1
Spread the risk among many investors: Assets held in an SPV are funded by debt and equity investments, spreading the risk of the assets among many investors and limiting the risk to each investor.
Easy to set up: Depending on where you set up the SPV, it often requires very little cost and can be done in as little as 24 hours in some cases. Furthermore, there is little to no governmental authorization needed to establish the entity.
Corporations can isolate risks from the parent company: Corporations benefit from isolating certain risks from the parent company. For example, should the assets experience a substantial loss in value, it wouldn't directly affect the parent company.
Cons Explained
Lack of transparency: Some SPVs can be very complex, with many layers of securitized assets. This complexity can make it very difficult to track the level of risk involved.
Lack of regulation: The regulatory standards that apply to the parent company do not necessarily apply to the assets held in the SPV, posing an indirect risk to the firm and investors.
Reputational risk to the parent company: If the performance of the assets within the SPV is worse than expected, it could still hurt the reputation of the parent company.
Liquidity risks: If the assets in the SPV do not perform well, it will be difficult for investors and the parent company to sell the assets back on the open market, creating a risk to the liquidity of the assets.
What It Means for Individual Investors
Individual investors should take note of companies that create SPVs as it may affect the investor’s decision to purchase shares of that company. Investors participating in the funding of an SPV should be clear about the purpose for the SPV, the financials, and the expected performance of its assets. 

Note
Investing directly in an SPV poses a higher risk than investing in other companies due to the lack of established reputation and historical performance. Investors may lack overall knowledge

a. Implementing successful projects and keeping operations running
b. Automating business processes
c. Being available for the organization as needed
Explain in your own words how these three actually provide value to organizations.
Provide examples supporting each.
7. What is a strategy? What is an IT strategic plan and why is it significant in aligning business objectives with IT?
8. What is an IT Steering Committee? Summarize the various activities included as part of its
scope.
9. Operationalization translates the understanding of both, organization and IT objectives, into operating plans. Operating plans identify and schedule the IT projects that will be initiated and the IT service levels that will be expected. Delivery of these operating plans should be controlled by a series of governance processes. List and describe these processes.
10. What is a Technical Steering Committee and what does it assess related to a technology solution?COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and related Technology) is a framework used to define governance and management of enterprise information and technology. According to COBIT, governance refers to the processes and policies that are put in place to ensure that an organization's information and technology resources are used effectively and efficiently to achieve the organization's goals and objectives.It is important for the business and its IT department to join efforts in delivering IT value because IT plays a critical role in supporting the business's operations and helping the business achieve its goals. By aligning the efforts of the business and IT, the organization can ensure that IT investments are aligned with the business's needs and objectives, and that IT is being used to support the business in the most effective way possible.The three widely recognized best practice IT-related frameworks are ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library), COBIT, and ISO/IEC 27002. ITIL is a framework that provides best practices for managing and delivering IT services. It is typically used in IT service management. COBIT is a framework that provides a set of best practices for governing and managing enterprise information and technology. It is typically used in IT governance. ISO/IEC 27002 is a standard that provides guidelines for information security management systems. It is typically used in information security management.Organizations may consider implementing a joint framework between ITIL, COBIT, and ISO/IEC 27002 because each of these frameworks addresses different aspects of IT management and governance. By combining these frameworks, organizations can create a comprehensive approach to managing and governing their IT resources that takes into account all of the different factors that impact IT effectiveness and efficiency.An IT balanced scorecard is a tool that is used to measure the performance of an organization's IT department. It typically includes metrics that reflect the value that IT is delivering to the business, such as cost savings, increased productivity, and improved customer satisfaction. The IT balanced scorecard is used to help align the goals of the IT department with the overall goals of the organization, and to ensure that the IT department is contributing to the overall success of the business.The three ways that IT can deliver value to an organization are:
a. Implementing successful projectsand keeping operations running: By successfully delivering IT projects, an organization can improve its operations and processes, leading to increased efficiency and effectiveness. For example, implementing a new customer relationship management system can help an organization better track and manage customer interactions, leading to improved customer satisfaction.
b. Automating business processes: By automating business processes, an organization can streamline its operations and reduce the need for manual labor. For example, automating the invoicing process can reduce the time and resources required to generate and send invoices, freeing up employees to focus on more value-added tasks.
c. Being available for the organization as needed: By providing reliable IT services, an organization can ensure that its employees have the tools and resources they need to do their jobs effectively. For example, if an organization has an IT support team that is available to troubleshoot problems and resolve issues quickly, employees will be able to work more efficiently and effectively, leading to increased productivity.A strategy is a plan or course of action designed to achieve a particular goal. An IT strategic plan is a document that outlines the long-term goals and objectives of an organization's IT department, and the actions that will be taken to achieve those goals. It is significant in aligning business objectives with IT because it helps ensure that the IT department is working towards goals that are aligned with the overall goals of the organization, and that IT investments are being made in a way that supports the business's overall strategy.An IT Steering Committee is a group of individuals responsible for overseeing the management and use of an organization's IT resources. The scope of an IT Steering Committee may include activities such as reviewing and approving IT projects, setting IT policies and standards, and monitoring the performance of the IT department.The governance processes that are used to control the delivery of operating plans may include activities such as:Planning: Developing a plan for how IT projects and services will be deliveredMonitoring and controlling: Tracking the progress of IT projects and services and taking corrective action as neededReviewing and evaluating: Periodically reviewing the performance of IT projects and services to ensure that they are meeting the organization's objectivesCommunicating: Ensuring that all stakeholders are kept informed about the status of IT projects and servicesA Technical Steering Committee is a group of individuals responsible for assessing the technical aspects of a technology solution. The committee may assess factors such as the technical feasibility of the solution, the compatibility of the solution with the organization's existing IT infrastructure, and the potential risks and benefits of the solution.Explain the governance process from demand management,project intiation,technical review,Procurement and Vendor Management,Financial Management!network error

Write a blog post about "How to use OpenAI’s ChatGPT to write the perfect cold email". Here's a summary of what it should be about:

`Finally, an AI text generator that sounds like it’s written by a human. Learn how OpenAI’s ChatGPT can help you write effective cold outreach emails with just a simple prompt.`

Write it in a conversational and humorous tone similar to Streak CRMs blog. It should be 1000-1200 words. Target the following keywords: "AI text generator", "Openai", "AI email assistant", "Chat GPT".

Target people looking to improve the results of their cold email outreach who are in email-based jobs (sales, marketing, fundraising, etc.) that are looking for new/creative ways to write cold emails.

Tie in how you could use Streak's Mail Merge feature along side ChatGPT text generation.

Here's the outline to use: 
- What are AI writing tools/assistants? How does AI work in this case? 
- What is OpenAI? What is ChatGPT?
- What exactly will you get/end up with by using this tool? (ex: writing suggestions? Autocomplete? Finished product? Subject line included?) 
- What are the benefits of using Chat GPT to write your emails?
- What are the limits/risks? 
- Step-by-step instructions on how to write/generate an email with ChatGPT

The post should also include the following tips on how to write well using ChatGPT:
- describe to chatgpt the type of product you are selling 
- tell it who ideal customers might be - ask it to generate other similar customer personas and industries 
- ask it to include placeholders where the email can be customized per recipient 
- ask it to add any calls to actions like booting a calendly meeting or encouraging an email response - tell it what kind of tone you want (informal or sales-y or something else) 
- tell it you want to optimize for conversion 
- ask it to generate a subject line 
- ask it to lengthen or shorten it based on preferences 
- ask it to generate alternative emails for the different target customers it identified
