I need your help with my assignment. I need to evaluate a venture pitch and write a report on it. I will first provide you with the group pitch, and then the assignment instructions so you can complete my assignment to help me achieve the highest possible grade. Below is the group pitch. Reply to this with 'yes' if you understand:

Helpmates: A holistic app that provides services for working professionals

Table of Contents:
1.	Executive Summary
2.	The Why
3.	The Context
4.	Business Model Canvas
5.	Product-Market Positioning
6.	Business Ecosystem
7.	Financials
8.	Implementation
9.	The Ask

1.	Executive Summary:
Problem Addressed:
•	Currently, most service providers operate independently, on specific platforms or by word of mouth.
•	Helpmates brings all service providers onto one, easy-access platform.
•	Consumers will benefit from an all-encompassing platform which facilitates the finding of service providers.
The Platform:
•	An app which connects service providers with consumers:
o	Consumers view range of services and service providers
o	Consumers pick providers based on profile including ratings, location and price
o	Consumers can book slots or message providers
•	Mainly monetized through commissions and advertisements
The Launch:
•	Launch in Sydney in 2023 amongst higher income customer segments, starting for household tasks (cleaning, gardening, plumbing, carpenting, etc.)
•	View to expand rapidly into other services once a strong service provider and customer base is established.

2.	The Why:
We came up with the idea of Helpmates out of personal experiences and by witnessing a gap in the market for a holistic services app. An app like Helpmates is specifically made for working professionals who are on a time crunch offering one click solutions for all household problems. The increasing number of working professionals and the fast-paced corporate culture laid down the need for an app like Helpmates. This is the only app currently in the market that offers hassle-free solutions and booking for top certified professionals.

3.	The Context:
According to the PESTEL AND Porter's 5 Forces analyses:
•	Australia is a fast-growing economy and citizens are always looking for ways to save time.
•	Australia is an early adopter of technology making Helpmates easy to be implemented in the society.
•	The service industry is fast paced and ever changing and an app like Helpmates can help bring a wave of change in which people use professional services.
•	The service industry has significant potential. Helpmates provides high quality services at the best prices that the market has to offer.

4.	Business Model Canvas:
Key Partners:
•	Freelancers
•	Local communities
•	Small businesses
•	Software developers
Key Activities:
•	Connect service providers with customers
•	Encourage freelancing
Key Resources
•	Large no. of users & service providers
•	Capital
•	App developer
Cost Structure:
•	Software Development cost
•	App Operating cost
•	Marketing cost
Value Proposition:
•	Easy and flexible service
•	Easily accessible
•	Trust
•	Creating new income/job opportunities
Customer Relationships:
•	Customer service
•	Feedback/ratings
Channels:
•	LinkedIn
•	Community
•	Facebook groups
•	Social media
Customer Segments:
•	Service users
•	Busy professionals
•	New-to-community service providers
•	Freelancers
•	Small businesses
•	Students
Revenue Streams:
•	Commissions
•	Advertisements
•	Service Provider Boost (to show providers on top of list)

5.	Product-Market Positioning:
Problems Customers Faced:
•	One Sided Platform: Supplier-oriented only or consumer-oriented only
•	Lack of Connection: Hard to find out service suppliers or service consumers
•	Lack of Efficiency: Long waiting time for reply and service delivery
•	Diverse Channels: Various platforms for different types of service
•	Lack of Accessibility: Difficult access to the service provider
•	Lack of Supply: Lack of personal services in wider areas
Market Positioning:
•	Target Market:
o	Personal Service (including all types of personal services)
o	Initial Focus: Low-skilled + High Demand (Clean/Housekeeping,
o	Cafe/Restaurant, etc.)
•	Customers Segments:
o	Service Suppliers - Everyone who needs services
o	Service Consumers - Everyone who is willing to provide services
•	Early Adopter Target Customers:
o	Service Suppliers: Freelancers & Students
o	Service Consumers: New to community & Small businesses
•	Advantages/Values:
o	Inclusivity & diversity (service coverage & user coverage)
o	Strengthening community connection
o	Empowering users to develop skills and gain jobs
o	Guaranteed for services and payments

6.	Business Ecosystem:

provide services

9.	Implementation:
Lean Startup Method:
1.	Assumptions:
•	Freelancers need more jobs
•	Busy working individuals need more help with house services
•	Time consuming to search for help with some services
2.	Survey (Current Status):
•	Survey the interest and needs of the target customer
•	Target working professionals, Sydney CBD, LinkedIn, and survey small business and freelancers to know if they are interested
3.	Analyze the data (April 2023):
•	Above 70% positive results  move ahead with MVP for all the questions
•	Less than 70% → Pivot makes changes to meet customer needs
4.	Design MVP (July 2023):
•	App with basic features
•	Small area - Sydney CBD
•	Most commonly needed services
•	Partner with freelancers to join the platform
•	Feedback Included
•	Spread the word using LinkedIn
5.	Persist/Pivot/Perish (October 2023):
•	Success Criteria: Good Feedback (80% or 4+ star rating); at least 40-50 customer signups and transactions per month for the first 2 months; good User Growth
•	PIVOT: Only 50% positive feedback or ~less than 40 Users.
•	PERISH: 70% Negative feedback or ~10 Users; no User Growth.

10.	Implementation (Continued):
Current Status:
•	Created a survey
•	Sending the survey to currently working professionals
•	Receiving feedback and interest in our app
•	Survey on LinkedIn as it has a large number of working professionals who have busy lives and would need help to maintain their house or other home services
MVP Test:
•	App developer
•	UX/UI designer
•	Funding through bootstrapping
•	Gain a large number of users to test the product

11.	The Ask (Investment Proposal):
The Opportunity:
•	Invest in Helpmates pre-launch
•	App to aggregate and simplify searching for a large variety of services in one easy-access platform
•	Promoting accessible casual and freelance employment
•	Simple and low cost platform with potential for large commission based earnings
Offer:
•	Investment of $50,000 for 10% equity
Use:
•	$30,000 investment in targeted marketing for Sydney home service providers
•	$20,000 incentives and referral bonus for launch to increase service providers
Desired Outcome:
•	Large-scale influx of service providers in the area to increase offering for customers
Additional Requests:
•	Networking with digital marketing professionals
•	Networking with a SaaS CTO to help drive the and UI/UX
Next Steps:
•	Increase service types offering (e.g. babysitting, tutoring, bartending, hairdressing, etc.)
•	Expand into new regions with initial investments and incentives to boost app uptake
•	Continue spending 30% of revenue on marketing in order to expand the business and grow users

In the interim, and as a thank you for your support to date, we are holding an Early-Bird Bonus Draw on 7th January 2023.  Everyone who has bought a ticket up to and including 5th January will have a chance to win one of the following bonus prizes:

55” Samsung Smart 4K HDR TV
Samsung Galaxy Tab A8 Tablet
€250 Country Crest Voucher
Fitbit Versa 3 Smartwatch
Annual digital subscription to Irish Farmers Monthly magazine & the Irish Farmers Journal
We’ll be contacting the lucky bonus draw winners after the 7th January and will be contacting the winners of our extended main draw after the revised date of 10th March.

With the support of donors like you we have delivered more than 650 tonnes of food, warm clothing, medical supplies, and hygiene products to families in Ukraine and the proceeds of our draw will allow us to continue this vital work into 2023. As always, thank for your support to date and the very best of luck in the bonus draw.

JOB ADVERTISEMENT
Marketing Manager
Location – Auckland or Wellington


ABOUT TEG:
TEG is an integrated Live Entertainment, Ticketing and Technology business and a market leader in
the sports and entertainment industry. They are proud partners of some of the world’s largest and
most iconic venues as well as leading event promoters globally. TEG Includes Ticketek, TEG Live,
Eventopia, Qudos Bank Arena, Softix and The Entertainment Store. Their success is built upon more
than 35 years’ experience in the New Zealand and Australian market with a long standing and iconic
presence in the live entertainment and sporting industry.
Ticketek New Zealand’s unrivalled data driven marketing capabilities are powered by advanced digital
platforms and an unmatched customer database, containing over 35 years of live event data and over
11 million unique identities.
ROLE SUMMARY:
As Marketing Manager, you will be responsible for the overall development of Ticketek New Zealand’s
marketing campaigns across web, eDM, and social media, printed material and signage with the
primary goal of increasing ticket sales for their various events through these channels and partners.
You will oversee the Marketing Department which has overall responsibility for the management of
Client and Customer facing communications/branding, affiliate partnerships and digital marketing. You
will be required to build and execute campaigns that leverage Ticketek New Zealand’s channels to
gain maximum exposure, reach and cut through and generate maximum sales for their events and
partnership brands.
DESIRED SKILLS & EXPERIENCE:
Relevant experience working within marketing, digital marketing and / or similar positions
A track record of delivering successful marketing and brand campaigns, especially across digital
media and database marketing
Ability to manage multiple projects and meet tight timelines and demonstrated ability to
successfully work with a diverse range of stakeholders at all levels
Outstanding relationship management, leadership and influencing skills with proven ability for
managing multiple stakeholder groups.
Management and analysis of data and analytics to drive business outcomes
A tertiary degree in marketing, communications and/or similar discipline
A passion for media, entertainment, sport and / or events will be an advantage
This is a fantastic opportunity to lead the development and execution of marketing campaigns to
maximise exposure, reach and sales whilst working closely with many of New Zealand’s biggest
entertainment brands, venues and events.
APPLICATIONS CLOSE – Monday 23 rd January 2023
TO APPLY
Please send your resume with cover letter to: richard@globalelitesports.com
Global Elite Sports (www.globalelitesports.com) have been contracted on behalf of Ticketek New
Zealand to undertake the recruitment for this appointment.

Here's some context that one of our new clients Amanda Scarborough submitted in the Market Research Questionnaire.... Provide a summary below.

The form "Market Research Questionnaire For New Clients" has been submitted with the following information:

Your Company Name: Amanda Scarborough - Pitching Angel

To date, what has been the primary offer you've made to your audience?: Geared toward pitcher's themselves: Foundation Maximizer Program* Accuracy Maximizer Program Velocity Maximizer Program = Pitcher's Trifecta Bundle * can be purchased by itself, 5% of purchasers during March 2023 enrollment got Foundation ONLY, 95% of sales were some Trifecta >> https://www.pitching-angel.com/foundation Coach Maximizer Series - pitching training for coaches. pitcher's parents are encouraged to buy as well >>> https://www.pitching-angel.com/coach These are the primary offers. There are other add-ons/upsells I have: a. Intro to Movement - mini course on movement pitches (for pitchers AND parents) b. Inner Circle- additional drills and workouts, only available for people who purchase trifecta (for pitchers) c. Coaching Up Confident Pitchers - for coaches and parents of pitchers about communicating with their pitcher The Pitching Angel Experience - 3 day, in person pitching event. the first one was Dec 2022

Does this offer have buyers yet?: 3200+ for Foundation....850 for Coach Maximizer Series.....1250 for Intro to Movement

Who are the main buyers?: Trifecta: Parents of pitchers buying for their daughters. Biggest % of pitchers fall between ages 9-12. There are older pitchers 13+ included in there, as well as some college aged and beyond who work through the course. USUALLY this pitcher is more in her beginner to intermediate stages. Coach Course: Pitching coaches who coach pitchers in high school or travel ball or college, pitching coaches who give private lessons, an old baseball player who now is having to learn softball pitching, parents of pitchers who don't have my trifecta, parents of pitchers who DO have my trifecta, parents who are supportive and instrumental and involved in their pitcher's pitching journey. Recently made a post on my Facebook page asking people this same question, "who are you"? https://www.facebook.com/amanda9scarborough/posts/pfbid022Nd1zGgrfz6GjfNzxacoSm5m3VqtP859KQEWf1G56GVJeEKx7K8kPtRPddj8X3aXl?__cft__[0]=AZXO4iXV8DRIK0Eiv_ujYxaYJkp0mlCl0X7MqFIm_oV8D9JV4BJHiZlf3f7xB7Up9BwuqJSWXcgV_NHNS53FoOnDPLre0CfSj0IDiuzl9vdjivUZdQ-HNyHQ2qsXaElXal4&__tn__=%2CO%2CP-R

What do they want/desire more than anything else?: Trifecta: CONFIDENCE & self-belief for their child. Parents want their pitcher to reignite their love/passion for pitching. They want their pitcher to have fun and put in the work. They want to know she is learning the right things mechanically when it comes to pitching. They want her to stay healthy mentally and physically while playing/learning a position she's interested in. They want "her light to shine". Ultimately, they want their daughter to have more pitching time, but it's based on everything listed before this. As a side note: an indirect benefit that I did not expect, but one that so many all say, is how through the course they create a "common language" with their pitcher and they're able to communicate and work with their pitcher in a way that makes everything seem easier and get on the same page together. Coach: If it's a parent buying, they want a way to learn how to help their pitcher when she's practicing at home outside of lessons. The parent wants to make sure he/she is not "messing her up" and telling her the wrong thing. If it's a team coach buying, they want a way to communicate with pitchers who all work with different private coaches. If it's a coach who gives lessons buying, they want new drills, new communication and to get insight as to how/what I teach to be able to bring it to their lessons. The REAL desire of a coach for this coach course could definitely use some more insight and understanding. It has always come second fiddle to my training for pitchers, but has just as much potential as the pitching training itself.

What's the main reason they buy?: Trifecta: They don't have a pitching coach near them. OR They have a pitching coach, but they want focused work to put in in between lessons. OR The pitcher has plateau'd in speed and results. OR They simply want new drills & workouts. OR They want to make sure they're learning the "right" thing. Coach: As a parent buying, they want information to better support their pitcher. As a coach buying, they want a fresh approach, new drills and workouts to implement with their pitcher.

What is the biggest problem or challenge they are facing right now?: Trifecta: Lack of confidence, lack of work ethic, lack of pitching speed, a mechanical habit they cannot fix, a plateau in speed, inconsistency from the pitcher they see at practice to the pitcher they see during a game, inconsistency with accuracy, getting "stuck". Coach: same as above. Overwhelmed with the amount of information that's out there on pitching.

What frustrates them?: Trifecta: How hard pitching is. The unknown about pitching. Not knowing if what they're learning is the right thing. Having to google a ton of drills and find them on their own somewhere on the internet. A pitching coach who is teaching them the wrong thing. No direction in terms of what should be learned first and any type of progression. Also....wasting time either learning the wrong things or wasting time pitching, only to see their daughter quit pitching. Coach: Really, the same answer as above.

What causes them pain?: Trifecta: seeing their daughter struggle. seeing their daughter not pitch to her potential. Coach: as a parent who buys, seeing their daughter struggle and want to quit. as a coach who buys, losing games, their pitcher not being able to get out of an inning, not being able to communicate with a pitcher

What are their insecurities?: Trifecta: that their pitcher will never figure it out, money & time being wasted, that their pitcher isn't "tall enough" or "good enough" to do it, that their pitcher isn't pitching a certain speed by a certain age, that their pitcher isn't up to the level as other pitchers on her team. Write a 3000 word article about corporate mission statements and purpose driven organizations. Be sure to identify the different types of mission statements, provide several examples of each, discuss the positives and negatives of each type as compared to one another and also include suggested processes for developing a mission statement.
Corporate mission statements are often considered a vital part of any organization. They are used to define the purpose and goals of the organization, and they serve as a guide for decision-making and strategy development. A well-crafted mission statement can help an organization focus its efforts, communicate its values to stakeholders, and inspire its employees.There are several types of mission statements that organizations can choose from. These include:Market-oriented mission statements: These mission statements focus on the needs of the organization's customers and the value that the organization provides to them. They often include language about the organization's products or services, and how they meet the needs of its customers. Examples of market-oriented mission statements include:Amazon: "Our vision is to be earth's most customer-centric company, where customers can find and discover anything they might want to buy online."Coca-Cola: "To refresh the world in mind, body, and spirit, to inspire moments of optimism and happiness through our brands and actions."Product-oriented mission statements: These mission statements focus on the organization's products or services, and the unique benefits they offer. They may include language about the organization's commitment to quality, innovation, or sustainability. Examples of product-oriented mission statements include:Tesla: "To accelerate the world's transition to sustainable energy."Nike: "To bring inspiration and innovation to every athlete in the world."Public service mission statements: These mission statements focus on the impact that the organization has on society, and its commitment to making a positive difference. They may include language about the organization's values, and its responsibility to stakeholders. Examples of public service mission statements include:Patagonia: "Build the best product, cause no unnecessary harm, use business to inspire and implement solutions to the environmental crisis."UNICEF: "To defend the rights of every child, everywhere, every day, and to help children survive and thrive, from early childhood through adolescence."Societal mission statements: These mission statements focus on the organization's commitment to making a positive impact on society, and aligns with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). They are relatively new types of mission statement that mainly used by companies that want to contribute to a more sustainable world. Examples of societal mission statements include:IKEA: "To create a better everyday life for the many people."The Body Shop: "To dedicate our business to the pursuit of social and environmental change."All of these types of mission statements have their own advantages and disadvantages. Market-oriented mission statements, for example, can help an organization stay competitive by focusing on customer needs. Product-oriented mission statements can help an organization differentiate itself from competitors by highlighting the unique benefits of its products or services. Public service mission statements can help an organization build trust with stakeholders by highlighting its commitment to making a positive impact on society. However, societal mission statements can help organizations align its activities with the global goals for sustainable development.On the other hand, market-oriented mission statements can also be seen as shallow or superficial, if they don't address the impact of their operations on society or the environment. Product-oriented mission statements can be criticized if they don't take into account the social and environmental impact of the production. Public service mission statements can be criticized if they don't address the organization's impact on society in a concrete way.Developing a mission statement can be a challenging process, but there are several steps that organizations can take to make it easier. These include:Defining the organization's values: Before developing a mission statement, it's important to define the organization's valuesGenerate a detailed outline for this artcle in sections and sub sectionsI. By taking the time to define these elements, organizations can create a mission statement that truly reflects the purpose and direction of the company.The first step in the process is to define the organization's values. These are the principles that guide the organization's decision-making and actions. They can include things like integrity, innovation, or social responsibility. By clearly defining these values, the organization can ensure that they are reflected in its mission statement.Once the values have been defined, the next step is to identify the organization's stakeholders. These are the people or groups that have a vested interest in the organization's success. They can include customers, employees, shareholders, and members of the community. By taking the time to understand the needs and concerns of these stakeholders, the organization can ensure that its mission statement addresses their interests and concerns.With a clear understanding of its values and stakeholders, the organization can then determine its purpose and goals. What is the company's ultimate objective? What does the company want to achieve in the short and long term? This step is crucial to make sure that the mission statement aligns with the overall direction and purpose of the organization.Once the organization has a clear understanding of its values, stakeholders, and goals, it can begin to draft different versions of the mission statement. It's important to keep in mind that a mission statement should be clear, concise, and memorable. It should be easy to understand and communicate to all stakeholders. It's also important to test these different versions with different groups of people to see how they resonate with them.After testing the different versions, it's time to finalize the mission statement. This is the statement that will guide the organization's decisions and actions. Once the final version is chosen, it's important to communicate it to all stakeholders. This could be through internal communications, on the company's website, or even through advertising. It's essential that everyone within the organization understands the mission statement and is aligned with the purpose and direction of the company.In conclusion, developing a mission statement is an essential process for any organization. They should align with the overall direction and purpose of the organization, and they should be relevant to its mission statement.By clearly defining these values, the organization can ensure that they are reflected in its mission statement. Please provide the following information about your company and company founders.
Company Name: Soshi


Company URL (if applicable): www.soshi.org 



Team Composition (Name / Email / Major / Year)
Jason Steinberg / jason@soshi.app / Computer science major with a general business minor at the University of Maryland / Junior
Yuvan Sundrani / uv@soshi.app / Information science major specializing in data science with computer science minor at the University of Maryland / Junior
Sri Kanipakala / sri@soshi.app / Computer science major with technology entrepreneurship minor/ Junior
Describe what your company does / will do and what problem it solves.
The average person aged 18-29 has 6+ social media handles. They would love to exchange multiple handles with people they meet, but it's impossible to do so without coming across as "weird". With only one platform exchanged, they know nothing about each other, which leads to boring conversations that die out quickly. You only have one chance to swap one piece of info with someone you just met.
Soshi empowers you to capitalize on this chance. We are a mobile app that allows you to share all of your contact & social media info in one place, with one tap. Our mission is to help people keep the conversation going. 
 
Are you currently engaged in any other incubator or accelerator programs? If so, which ones:
We are not part of any other incubator or accelerator programs, but we are Founders in Startup Shell.
 
Describe how your team will benefit from having dedicated desk space in the hatchery.
We’re always working in different places. We need a set meeting place that we can depend on to have the atmosphere and resources we need to be productive. The Hatchery offers just this—with quality monitors, whiteboards, storage space, and other like minded individuals—and conveniently happens to be a midpoint between our team’s apartments.


What is the ownership breakdown of the founders and/or investors?
The ownership of Soshi is split among our three founders and Sri Kanipakala (developer). Jason and UV each own 40%, Sri owns 15%, and Sid owns 5%. No investors or third parties have equity in the company as of now. 

Where did you come up with the idea and why did you choose it?
jason
(From the perspective of Sid Jagtap - Co-Founder)
I was watching an episode of The Office one night. In the episode, Ryan starts a venture called WUPHF: a platform that would allow people to send a single message and have it delivered in multiple mediums to the recipient. Jim could send a simple “hey” to Dwight, and Dwight would get the message not just over text, but also over email, fax, phone; you name it.
Although this idea was a joke, it created a spark in my head, leading me to the solution to a problem I encountered all the time. The problem would usually go like this: I would meet and add a girl usually over snapchat, and the conversation stays on the surface until one of us gets bored and stops replying. How am I supposed to keep the conversation going when I know nothing about them? 
Just like how WUPHF allowed people to access multiple platforms through one entry point, I thought about how this concept could change the game in my social life. What if when I meet someone new, I could share not just my number, but all of my social media info? Breaking the ice would be 10 times easier. Shortly after, I called Uv and Jason to tell them my idea and right there Soshi was born; with the mission of helping people like us turn first conversations into lasting connections.



What is new about the idea? 
The idea of compacting social media handles into one place exists, but only in the professional world. Soshi tailors this idea to a different market: the social scene. 
In order to provide a fun, socially acceptable, and efficient way to swap info, we allow people to express themselves beyond just their social media accounts. 
We have integrated “passions” to serve as icebreakers, and a casual & fun UI designed specifically for the social scene. Also, with our new “Soshi Groups” feature, users can create a group, joinable through a single “Soshi code” and every member is able to see and share their socials with others in the group. Greek life organizations, clubs, athletic teams, resident halls and other groups can create their own Soshi groups to quickly connect their members.


Who are existing competitors in the market and how big are they? 
Blue Social: ~50k users
Link.me: ~500K users
Dot: users undisclosed

How will the company make money?
We plan to monetize first by selling Soshi portals, which allow users to share their profile using NFC. Focusing on the college market (19.4 million students), of which ~55% identify as "extroverts" and use multiple social media accounts, making our target market ~10.67 million people.
At $9/unit (~$7 profit), we could generate up to $96.03 million in revenue (or $74.69 million in profit) within our target market alone.
Due to the low LTV per customer with NFC products, we also plan to explore other ways to monetize at greater scale (premium features & partnerships with bars/venues).


What do you uniquely know, understand, or have access to that puts you in a position to be successful with this idea?
We live the life of our target customer—as social college students, we know that people like us want to exchange all sorts of social media info when they first connect with someone. As our users have told us, having lots of surface level info on a person makes breaking the ice 10 times faster and easier. 
There are “digital business cards'' out there, but here’s the thing: People are going to give you some weird looks if you’re passing around your “digital business card” at a bar. We know that people need a fun, casual, and socially acceptable way to swap multiple social media handles at once, and this does not exist in today’s market.
Each of us having 3+ years in entrepreneurship and 3+ years in software development, we believe we are the right team to satisfy this need.

Is there a social mission/social benefit that your company advances?
We encourage people to take the step outside and experience that in-person, face-to-face conversation. We’ve received lots of feedback from our users and thanking us for making connecting with someone so easy!

Optional: You may submit a 1 minute video introducing the CEO & Founder describing your idea and why it is a good idea.


Is there anything else we should know about your company and/or why you should be admitted to the Hatchery program? 
Having been friends with Thai (Mindgrasp), Bryan (Quandary), and Zach (Shellter), members of last year’s batch, we have heard great things about the program. With our app just having reached 1k users through organic growth, we could greatly benefit from the resources and mentorship provided by the Hatchery to further scale, improve engagement, and take our startup to the next level.
Unlike most companies, our work goes hand-in-hand with our social life. We are continuously working, going out and meeting new people, and using Soshi to turn those people into both connections and new users. 

"

Dutch chip equipment maker ASML's CEO questions US export rules on China -newspaper 
AMSTERDAM :The chief executive of ASML Holding NV, the Dutch semiconductor equipment maker, on Tuesday questioned whether a U.S. push to get the Netherlands to adopt new rules restricting exports to China make sense.

"Maybe they think we should come across the table, but ASML has already sacrificed," CEO Peter Wennink said in an interview with newspaper NRC Handelsblad.

He said that following U.S. pressure, the Dutch government has already restricted ASML from exporting its most advanced lithography machines to China since 2019, something he said has benefited U.S. companies selling alternative technology.

He said that while 15 per cent of ASML's sales are in China, at U.S. chip equipment suppliers "it is 25 or sometimes more than 30 per cent".

A spokesperson for ASML confirmed the remarks in the interview were accurate but declined further comment.

The Biden administration issued new export rules for U.S. companies in October aimed at cutting off China's ability to manufacture advanced semiconductor chips in a bid to slow its military and technological advances.

Washington is urging the Netherlands, Japan and other unspecified countries with companies that make cutting edge manufacturing equipment to adopt similar rules. The Dutch trade minister has confirmed talks are ongoing.

Wennink said it seemed contradictory that U.S. chip manufacturers are able to sell their most advanced chips to Chinese customers, while ASML is only able to sell older chipmaking equipment.
"American chip manufacturers have no problem with China as a customer," he said.
Meanwhile, "it is common knowledge that chip technology for purely military applications is usually 10, 15 years old. (Yet) the technology used to make such chips can still be sold to China," he added.

Serverless Tier sells Processing Units and Row/Column Storage, and users do not need to be aware of computing resources. Serverless Pricing （WIP） 
Therefore, in a monitoring scenario, it is sufficient to provide the user with SQL-level and DB-level data.
Objective
Final Goals
List product goals including their timeframe, and success metric
Goal：
- On Serverless Tier
  - Provide Cluster-level and DB-level monitoring to users.
Non-Goal：
- On Serverless Tier
  - Monitoring of cluster-level is not provided
  - Monitoring of computing resources is not provided
  - Monitoring of internal system logic is not provided
  - This document does not provide detailed monitoring within the database (such as whether data or indexes are consuming storage space), which will be provided in Monitoring section of Database Page on Serverless Tier document."
Target user / role
Who the product is for
- End User: Only uses the database, does not care about any system logic, only cares about the performance and success of their own SQL.
User Scenarios / Story
A detailed list of user scenarios
Scenarios 1
User A is running a website that heavily relies on a database for storing and retrieving data. They want to ensure that their website is running smoothly and efficiently. 
They use the Serverless Tier's monitoring feature to check the Cluster Overview tab for metrics such as Query Per Second and Average Query Duration to see how many queries are being executed and how long they are taking on average. They also check the Failed Queries tab to see if there are any errors occurring in the database.
Scenarios 2
User B is running a mobile application that uses a database to store user information and track in-app purchases. They want to ensure that the database is able to handle the high volume of transactions that are occurring. 
They use the Serverless Tier's monitoring feature to check the Transaction tab for metrics such as Transaction Per Second and Average Transaction Duration to see how many transactions are being executed and how long they are taking on average. They also check the Transaction Retry Num to see if there are any retries happening and the Acquire Pessimistic Locks Duration to see how much time is taken to lock the table.
Scenarios 3
User C is a developer working on a project that uses a database to store and retrieve data. They want to ensure that the database is performing well and that there are no issues that need to be addressed. 
They use the Serverless Tier's monitoring feature to check the Connection tab for metrics such as Connection Count and Active Connection to see how many connections are currently open to the database, and how many of them are active.
Scenarios 4
User D is running a game platform that uses a database to store and retrieve user information, game progress and leaderboard information. They want to ensure that the database is able to handle the high volume of queries and transactions that are occurring during peak gaming hours. 
They use the Serverless Tier's monitoring feature to check the Cluster Overview tab to see the overall performance of the cluster and then check the Query, Transaction, Session and Connection tabs to see the details of the queries, transactions, sessions and connections. They also check the Failed Queries tab to see if there are any errors or issues with the queries.
Feature Lists
Information Structure - Monitoring Page
This content is only supported in a Feishu Docs
Functional Specs
All the product interface and user-perceivable behavior changes need to be described in detail, including but not limited to:
1. Any changes to GUI and command line, including command parameters and parameter definition changes;
2. Any changes to the configuration items or system variables, including changes in value ranges and value semantics;
3. Any changes to the storage directory and file format of the data;
4. Any API and network protocol changes, including changes in the format of transmission content;
5. Any user-visible output format or semantic changes, such as execution plan, diagnostic information, and error information, logs, alarms, etc. that affect user decision-making.
Entry: 
- Serverless Tier
  - Left Navigation
    - 
  - Cluster Overview

Tab: Cluster Status
[Image]
- Tab
  - Default tab is "Cluster status".
  - Users can click the bottom to another tab.
- Time Picker
  - All monitoring data is available for 2 days.
- Metrics Name
  - Query Level
    - Metrics Name "Query Per Second": The number of SQL statements executed per second on the Serverless Tier, which is counted according to SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, and other types of statements.
    - Metrics Name "Average Query Duration": The duration from receiving a request from the client to the Serverless Tier till the Serverless Tier executing the request and returning the result to the client. In general, client requests are sent in the form of SQL statements; however, this duration can include the execution time of commands such as COM_PING, COM_SLEEP, COM_STMT_FETCH, and COM_SEND_LONG_DATA.
    - Metrics Name "Failed Queries": The statistics of error types (such as syntax errors and primary key conflicts) according to the errors occurred when executing SQL statements per minute on the Serverless Tier. It contains the module in which the error occurs and the error code.
  - Command Level
    - Metrics Name "Command Per Second": The number of commands processed by the Serverless Tier per second, which is classified according to the success or failure of command execution results.
  - Transaction Level
    - Metrics Name "Transaction Per Second": The number of transactions executed per second.
    - Metrics Name "Average Transaction Duration": The execution duration of a transaction.
    - Metrics Name "Transaction Retry Num": The number of times that a transaction retries.
    - Metrics Name "Acquire Pessimistic Locks Duration": The time consumed by adding locks.
  - Connection Level
    - Metrics Name "Connection Count": The number of clients connected to the Serverless Tier.
    - Metrics Name "Active Connection": The number of active connections to the Serverless Tier. "Active" means the query is holding a token and under running.
    - Metrics Name "Average Idel Connection Duration": The connection Idle duration indicates the duration of a connection being idle.
Tab: DB Status
[Image]
- Metrics Name
  - Metrics Name "QPS Per DB": The number of SQL statements executed per second on every DB, which is counted according to SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, and other types of statements.
  - Metrics Name "Average Query Duration Per DB": The duration from receiving a request from the client to every DB till the Serverless Tier executing the request and returning the result to the client.
  - Metrics Name "Failed Query Per DB": The statistics of error types (such as syntax errors and primary key conflicts) according to the errors occurred when executing SQL statements per minute on every DB.
  - Metrics Name "Storage Per DB": The storage size per DB. The storage includes data and index store size.

i want you to look at text 1 and text 2 and combine them into a great piece of text that incorporates points from both, make it so that the length of your output is nearly equal to text 1 + text 2:

text 1:
The S&P 500 had its worst annual performance since the global financial crisis of 2008-2009, marking the first annual decline since 2018. The global economy in 2022 suffered a metaphorically significant blow, similar to a heart attack. Just as a person needs time and patience to recover from a heart attack before returning to their normal routine, the market also needs time and patience to fully recover. It is unlikely that the market will return to the stability it experienced at the end of 2021, even if inflation begins to decrease. It is important to remember that market volatility and declines are a normal part of the long-term investment process, and these downturns can often turn into opportunities. It is how we handle adverse market conditions that can set us up for potential future success. This year has provided valuable investment lessons, including the fact that some of the strongest market rallies have occurred unexpectedly. We saw this in the double-digit rallies that occurred during the summer and fall, even when it seemed like the equity markets could only go lower. Remember that every bull market has its roots in a bear market and extreme market volatility often signifies the arrival of new investment themes and leadership.


text 2:
It's no secret that the past year has been a difficult one for all of us. The market has faced unprecedented challenges, and as a result, many of us have seen our portfolios take a significant hit. I know that this can be a very unsettling and worrying time, and I want to assure you that despite the short-term turbulence, we remain confident in the long-term prospects of the companies in which we have invested.

At Berkshire Hathaway, we have always focused on the fundamentals of a company, rather than trying to chase short-term market trends. We look for businesses that have strong management teams, a competitive advantage, and the ability to withstand economic downturns. These are the types of companies that will not only weather the storm, but also come out even stronger on the other side.

We also take a long-term perspective when it comes to investing. We don't try to time the market or make decisions based on short-term fluctuations. Instead, we look for solid companies that we believe will continue to grow and prosper over the long haul. This approach may not always result in immediate gains, but we believe it is the best way to build wealth over the long term.

So while the past year may have been a challenging one, we remain optimistic about the future. We are confident in the resilience and potential of the companies in which we have invested, and we believe that with a long-term perspective, our portfolios will recover and ultimately thrive. We understand that it can be difficult to stay the course during times of market turmoil, but we encourage you to keep a long-term perspective and to remain confident in your investment decisions. Thank you for your continued trust and confidence in us.

Sincerely,
Warren BuffetIt has been a difficult year for the market, with the S&P 500 experiencing its worst annual performance since the global financial crisis of 2008-2009, and marking the first annual decline since 2018. please identify the 10 main takeaways of the following article

"Zinssparen beim Broker
Trade Republic zahlt ab sofort 2% Zinsen auf nicht investiertes Geld. Ein bislang unschlagbares Angebot – das nicht ohne Hintergedanken daherkommt.
ETFs, Einzelaktien, Sparpläne – eigentlich sieht so das Metier des Neobrokers Trade Republic aus. Und so mussten bislang auch nur andere Aktien-Broker das Berliner Fintech als Wettbewerber fürchten. Seit dem vierten Januar hat sich der Konkurrenzkreis von Trade Republic erheblich vergrößert: Denn das Start-up hat sich zu einer Art Tagesgeldkonto gewandelt und bietet plötzlich bessere Konditionen als deutsche Direktbanken. Allen Kunden will der Broker ab sofort 2% Zinsen auf das nicht investierte Geld auf dem Verrechnungskonto zahlen. Das Angebot gilt für Cash-Guthaben bis 50.000€ und ist zeitlich unbefristet. Direktbanken wie die ING oder die Consorsbank haben zwar inzwischen ähnlich hohe Zinssätze zu bieten, allerdings gelten die nur für wenige Monate – anschließend rutschen die Guthabenzinsen für Kunden wieder in den Null-Komma-Irgendwas-Bereich ab. Was verspricht sich der Broker davon? Wie sicher ist das Geld bei Trade Republic und wie kann es sich das Fintech überhaupt leisten, seinen Kunden so viel Geld zu schenken? Und werden die Direktbanken bald nachziehen?

Trade Republic wirbt mit Zinseszinseffekt
“Die Zinsen werden live berechnet und, anders als bei vielen anderen Anbietern, monatlich ausgezahlt, woraus sich ein attraktiver Zinseszinseffekt ergibt”, heißt es in der offiziellen Pressemitteilung von Anfang Januar. Ein Zinseszinseffekt stellt sich durch die monatliche Ausschüttung zwar schon ein – ob man ihn als außerordentlich attraktiv bezeichnen möchte, dürfte aber Ansichtssache sein. Mal angenommen, ein Kunde hat 40.000€ auf dem Verrechnungskonto bei Trade Republic liegen. Bei 2% Zinsen müsste der Broker ihm im Jahr 800€ auszahlen. Werden die 2% dagegen monatlich gutgeschrieben, also immer wieder auf neuer, stetig steigender Grundlage berechnet, beläuft sich der Zinsertrag nach einem Jahr auf 807,37€. Ein Plus von 7€, das ganz nett ist, aber den Braten nicht unbedingt fett macht.

Seit wann zahlen Broker Zinsen?
Vielleicht muss man aber auch erst mal erklären, warum Trade Republic, das ja eigentlich als Broker gegründet wurde, überhaupt Guthaben-Zinsen zahlen darf. Der Grund ist, dass der Neobroker das Vermögen seiner Kunden nicht selbst verwaltet, sondern Geschäftsbanken dies für ihn übernehmen. Alles andere wäre auch illegal, denn als Broker besitzt Trade Republic keine Banklizenz. Eröffnen Kunden ein Depot, dann erhalten Sie automatisch ein Verrechnungskonto bei der Deutschen Bank oder bei der Citibank. Einige alte Trade Republic-Kunden lassen ihr Geld immer noch von der Solaris Bank verwahren, mit der das Start-up 2019 ursprünglich gestartet ist. Inzwischen stellt die Deutsche Bank den Großteil der Verrechnungskonten, auf die Kunden erst einmal Geld einzahlen müssen, um es anschließend an der Börse investieren zu können. Solche Partnerschaften sind ganz normal. Bei dem Konkurrenten Scalable Capital wird ein Konto bei der Baader Bank eröffnet, der Anbieter Smartbroker kooperiert mit der BNP PARIBAS. 

Das Geld ist sicher
Die Geschäftsbanken, die für Trade Republic-Kunden das Geld verwahren, sind allesamt regulierte Geldhäuser und werden von der Bafin überwacht. Sie alle unterliegen der europäischen Einlagensicherung, somit ist das Geld der Depotkunden – genau wie auf dem Tagesgeld-, Festgeld- und Girokonto – im Falle einer Bankenpleite geschützt. Zumindest bis zu einer Höhe von 100.000€.

Wie kann sich Trade Republic das leisten?
Aus welchen Mitteln will Trade Republic nun jedem der schätzungsweise über 2 Mio. Kunden 2% Zinsen bezahlen? Auch dafür muss man etwas ausholen und in das Zinsgeschäft der Banken einsteigen.

Geschäftsbanken haben die Möglichkeit, das Geld ihrer Kunden bei der EZB zu lagern, das Ganze nennt sich Einlagefazilität. Im Gegenzug erhalten sie dafür von der Zentralbank einen Zinssatz, den sogenannten Einlagesatz. In Zeiten einer strikten Nullzinspolitik lag der über Jahre im Minusbereich, die Banken mussten also ihrerseits der EZB Geld bezahlen, um ihr Geld dort parken zu dürfen – und haben die Mehrkosten an ihre Kunden weitergegeben. Anbieter von Girokonten, aber auch Broker, die mit betroffenen Geschäftsbanken kooperieren, haben also vielfach Negativzinsen erhoben. Jetzt, da der Einlagensatz als Reaktion auf die hohe Inflation bei 2% liegt und mutmaßlich noch weiter ansteigen wird, hat sich der Wind gedreht. Die Banken werden wieder belohnt für die Einlagen, die sie bei der EZB parken, und das verschafft auch den kooperierenden Brokern Mehreinnahmen. „Mit der Wiedereinführung der Zinsen durch die EZB reagieren wir zügig auf eine neue Marktsituation”, sagt Trade Republic-Chef Christian Hecker auf Anfrage. Man ermögliche den Kunden, ihr Geld auch dann für sich arbeiten zu lassen, wenn es noch nicht investiert ist. “Damit vereinen wir die wichtigsten Möglichkeiten, Geld anzulegen, in einer Anwendung. Einfach und demokratisch – wie es unserer Mission entspricht.”

Entwicklung Zinssatz der EZB für die Einlagefazilität von 1999 bis 2022
Entwicklung Zinssatz der EZB für die Einlagefazilität von 1999 bis 2022, Quelle: Statistisches Bundesamt
Ein Minusgeschäft?
Auch wenn es klingt, als würde Trade Republic den Einlagezins einfach an die Kunden weiterreichen, kann man davon ausgehen, dass der Broker ein Minusgeschäft macht. Schließlich wird zum Beispiel auch die Deutsche Bank einen Teil des Einlagezinses abhaben wollen, sodass Trade Republic unterm Strich vielleicht nur 1,5% davon übrig bleiben. Vielleicht kann die Deutsche Bank auch noch höhere Erträge herausholen, indem sie beispielsweise einen Teil der Kundengelder in Form von Krediten ausgibt. Dann kommen bei Deutsche Bank und Trade Republic vielleicht zusammen 2,5% an und Trade Republic kann 1,7% oder 1,8%  für sich behalten. Wie die Aufteilung genau ist, wissen nur die Unternehmen selbst, denn das ist Geschäftsgeheimnis.

Warum das Ganze?
Nun wird sich kein Unternehmen unüberlegt ins Minus stürzen, und auch Trade Republic dürfte sich sehr wohl etwas von der Zins-Offerte erhoffen. In der Pressemitteilung hat der Broker den Zweck des Ganzen nur oberflächlich angerissen: Man wolle die “Marktführerschaft als Europas größte Sparplattform ausbauen”, so die Begründung.

Wenn das Ziel gewesen sein sollte, einfach mal wieder die Werbetrommel zu rühren, dann ist das jedenfalls gelungen. In den Wirtschaftsmedien des Landes hatte Trade Republic schon kurz nach Ankündigung seinen Platz in den Schlagzeilen. Und allein das könnte dem Broker schon einen erheblichen Umsatz bescheren. Es wäre schließlich nicht überraschend, wenn Trade Republic mit dem neuen Angebot eine gewaltige Zahl an Neukunden gewinnen würde. Die Macher hinter dem Broker sind zumindest optimistisch: Bisher habe man sehr viel positives Feedback von Kunden zum Zinssparen bekommen, meint Mitgründer Christian Hecker. Man heiße jedenfalls jeden willkommen, der sein Geld für sich arbeiten lassen möchte.

Doch die Stimmung an den Börsen ist durch den Ukraine-Krieg und die damit verbundene Energiekrise weiterhin betrübt, und das dürfte auch der Neobroker in den vergangenen Quartalen durch eine rückläufige Zahl an Transaktionen zu spüren bekommen haben. Vielleicht sollen die neuen Zinsen also auch wieder zum Investieren anspornen: Um sie zu kassieren, müssen Kunden schließlich ein Depot eröffnen und Geld aufs Verrechnungskonto überweisen. So liegt es schon mal bereit in der App und damit nur einen Finger-Swipe entfernt von einem Investment. Die Schwelle zum Investieren ist also deutlich niedriger, wenn schon mal Geld da ist. Wir erinnern uns: Trade Republic verdient sein Geld vornehmlich mit Provisionen, die der Broker von ETF-Anbietern und Handelsplattformen erhält.

Vielleicht wird Trade Republic auch erst in ein paar Monaten so richtig profitieren, wenn die EZB erneut den Leitzins anhebt – und damit die Einnahmen für den Broker und seine Partnerbanken nochmals steigen. Gibt Trade Republic dann weiterhin “nur” 2% Zinsen weiter, fällt die Marge höher aus.

Wo ist der Haken?
Bei scheinbar kostenlosen Zinsgeschenken ist Misstrauen nicht unangebracht. Aber tatsächlich hat die Zins-Offerte von Trade Republic keinen Haken. Es gibt weder versteckte Kosten noch andere Fallstricke. Einziges Manko, wenn man so will, ist eine fehlende Garantie. Auch der Broker möchte kein Langzeit-Versprechen abgeben und die Zinsen gelten “bis auf Weiteres”, das heißt: Sie können theoretisch auch jederzeit wieder sinken oder komplett abgeschafft werden. “Es gibt eine Reihe von makroökonomischen Faktoren, die zu einer Änderung des Zinssatzes führen können”, schreibt Trade Republic dazu im FAQ-Bereich. Dazu gehörten auch “Änderungen des Leitzinses im Rahmen der Finanzpolitik der EZB.” Man werde die Kunden aber über jede Änderung frühzeitig informieren, heißt es weiter. Wie lange sich das Angebot halten wird, bleibt also abzuwarten. Sollte es etwa im Frühjahr wieder gekippt werden, wäre allerdings klar, dass Trade Republic doch keine besseren Konditionen bietet als die gewöhnlichen Direktbanken. Apropos: Wie stehen die eigentlich zur neuen Konkurrenz am Sichteinlagen-Himmel?

“Wir entscheiden in Ruhe”
Die Panik scheint bei den großen Direktbanken des Landes jedenfalls noch nicht ausgebrochen zu sein. Man entscheide “in Ruhe”, ob nun Anpassungen nötig sein sollten, sagt etwa ein Sprecher der Consorsbank. Als Direktbank der Marke BNP Paribas verwaltet das Institut rund 60 Mrd. Euro an Kundeneinlagen – und zahlt für Geld auf dem Tagesgeldkonto pro Jahr sogar 2,1% Zinsen. Das ist mehr als Trade Republic und gilt außerdem für Beträge von bis zu 1 Mio. Euro. Dafür ist das Angebot auf sechs Monate begrenzt, wer noch Wertpapiere dazu kauft, kann auf maximal ein Jahr verlängern. Könnte Trade Republic den Direktbanken nun nicht die Kunden streitig machen? Man beobachte kontinuierlich den Markt und prüfe das eigene Angebot auf Wettbewerbsfähigkeit, um dann bei Bedarf eine “Anpassung vorzunehmen”, heißt es aus der Kommunikationsabteilung. Auszuschließen ist also nicht, dass die Consorsbank ihre Zinsen nochmals anpassen wird.

2% Zinsen bietet die ING seinen Tagesgeld-Sparern. Vorausgesetzt, sie besaßen in den vergangenen sechs Monaten noch kein Tagesgeldkonto bei der ING. Das Angebot gilt ebenfalls nur befristet, schon nach vier Monaten müssen sich die Kunden wieder mit dem Basiszins von 0,3% pro Jahr begnügen. Anpassungen hält man auch hier (zumindest noch) nicht für notwendig: “Sollten es die weiteren Entwicklungen zulassen, werden wir auch beim Extra-Konto den Basiszins weiter erhöhen”, sagt ein Unternehmenssprecher und verweist darauf, dass man gerade erst vergangenen Dezember den Zins von 1% auf 2% angehoben habe. “Wir sind damit nach wie vor eine der wenigen Großbanken in Deutschland, die nennenswerte Zinsen für bestehende Konten beim Tagesgeld zahlen.”

Wer investieren will, sollte investieren
Mit seinen 2% Zinsen lässt Trade Republic gerade nicht nur die gesamte deutsche Brokerlandschaft, sondern auch viele Banken blass aussehen. Das Angebot ist überdurchschnittlich gut. So gut, dass es den ein oder anderen Anleger von seinem Ziel ablenken könnte. Gerade jetzt, da in vielen Depots die roten Zahlen dominieren, können so ein paar risikofreie 2% toll klingen. Wer sein Geld aber langfristig gewinnbringend anlegen möchte und dabei eher an 5-7% jährliche Rendite dachte, sollte auch dabei bleiben. Ja, die Stimmung an der Börse ist gerade betrübt und niemand weiß, ob es mit den Kursen der Welt-Indizes in den kommenden Monaten nicht noch weiter runtergehen wird. Trotzdem wird es sich langfristig auszahlen, auch in schlechten und extrem unwägbaren Situationen Geld am Aktienmarkt zu investieren. Gerade für solche Anleger, die noch 15, 20 oder mehr Jahr vor sich haben. Besser wäre es also, das Zinsangebot als das zu nehmen, was es ist: Ein nettes Zusatzangebot, das den ein oder anderen kleineren Betrag einbringen wird – aber keine solide Rendite, mit der sich das eigene Vermögen merklich vergrößern lässt."

Take these bullet points and write a white paper for my product, geared towards investors. The product is called Woven.

* Coordination is fundamental to human endeavor
* Yet we see coordination failures all around us
* When we improve human coordination, we are better positioned to change the world
* One key challenge is organizations with a common cause competing for resources
* We’ve seen a shift to networks, where the actors are organizations and people and government etc., working around a common cause, but the struggle to coordinate
* We need a better way for those networks with a common cause to raise funds and allocate those funds
* This better system must have a few key components: information discovery, fundraising, decision-making, and reputation
* Blockchain addresses perils around trust, transparency and centralization: we will connect the decision-making, fundraising/treasury, and reputation to the blockchain and progressively more later
* It should be very easy to use: spawn a new network which has a discussion forum and a wallet/treasury… and tools available to put forth initiatives and vote on them (such as how to allocate a portion of the money)
* Actors (or participants) on the network have profiles with reputation features: every participant can earn badges which are beautiful, artful statements of participation or impact
* Participants also earn reputation points from others, for their posts and activity… and this is weighed in the scoring for the discussion forum to elevate signal

Please write a proposal which meets the requirements of this request for proposal: "Please write a response to this request for proposal:  "Request for Proposal 


For

Virtual Reality training simulator for Personal Protective Grounding/Equal Potential Zones on the electric distribution underground system



 
 
1.	General Requirements 
1.1.	Introduction
Company invites you to submit a proposal for Bid Event Number 99909: Virtual Reality Training Simulator RFP event listed in PowerAdvocate.
SDG&E is a regulated public utility that provides safe and reliable energy service to 3.4 million consumers through 1.4 million electric meters and more than 855,000 natural gas meters in San Diego and southern Orange counties. The utility’s area spans 4,100 square miles. Exceptional customer service is a priority of SDG&E as it seeks to enhance the region's quality of life. SDG&E is a regulated subsidiary of Sempra Energy (NYSE: SRE). Sempra Energy, based in San Diego, is a Fortune 500 energy services holding company.

1.2.	EPIC Project Background 
The California Public Utilities Commission (“CPUC”) established the Electric Program Investment Charge (“EPIC”) to assist the development of non-commercialized new and emerging clean energy technologies in California while providing assistance to commercially viable projects. EPIC consists of three program areas: (1) Applied research and development; (2) Technology demonstration and deployment; and (3) Market facilitation, consisting of market research, regulatory permitting and streamlining, and workforce development activities. EPIC activities must be designed to produce electricity ratepayer benefits for San Diego Gas & Electric (“SDG&E”), Pacific Gas and Electric (“PG&E”), and Southern California Edison (“SCE”) customers. The annual EPIC budget of $162 million is collected from customers in electric utility bills at the following levels: PG&E (50.1%), SCE (41.1%), and SDG&E (8.8%). 
The California Energy Commission (“CEC”) administers 80% of the funding with the ability to invest in all of the approved EPIC activities; SDG&E, PG&E and SCE administer 20% of the funding with funding shares proportional to their respective collections and are limited to investing only in pre-commercial technology demonstrations. Of the 20% administered by the utilities, SDG&E’s share is only 1.76%. A portion of this 1.76% will be used to fund this project. Note that pre-commercial demonstrations must be for existing solutions and cannot be used for the development of new technology. . Links to each of the EPIC investment plans and the CPUC Decisions authorizing their execution and establishing programmatic requirements are on SDG&E’s public website:
https://www.sdge.com/epic


1.3.	RFP Objective and Purpose
The objective of this RFP is to select one or more contractors for the development of a Virtual Reality (“VR”) precommercial training simulator for Personal Protective Grounding/Equal Potential Zones (“PPG/EPZ”) on the electric distribution underground (“UG”) system. 

The purpose of this RFP is to solicit competitive bids to furnish and deliver certain services to Company, as further described herein. The information submitted in response to this RFP will be used to identify and evaluate Bidders who can provide, among other things, the most effective capabilities, quality, customer service to SDG&E, and competitive prices for the services performed.

1.4.	RFP Scope
This new training simulator will guide  one or more students using wireless VR googles with virtual hands  through five different scenarios. If VR goggles are not available, a student should be able to complete the training in two dimensions. The simulator should be able to assist the student through the five scenarios, test them on each scenario and retain records that the participant completed the training. The expected deliverables to be bidare:
1.	Five (5)  story boards total: one for each scenario 
2.	A two dimensional training simulator for each scenario
3.	A virtual reality for each scenario
4.	A learning management system (LMS) for each  scenario


Five (5) Different Scenarios:

1.	Replacing an elbow in a handhole with jacketed cable.

2.	Replacing a run of cable between two handholes with jacketed cable.   

3.	Replacing a “T” in a handhole with unjacketed and jacketed cable.

4.	Replacing a live front piece of equipment to a dead front with unjacketed cable.

5.	Changing a switch in a manhole."

The proposal should be at least 2000 words long.

Carbon emissions trading operates on the basis of the cap-and-trade principle, which sets a cap on the total amount of carbon emissions allowed within a specific period. This cap is then divided into permits that can be traded among companies that emit carbon. Companies that can reduce emissions below the allocated level can sell unused permits to companies that cannot do so, creating a market-based incentive for emissions reductions. Cap-and-trade schemes are designed to create market-driven incentives for companies to invest in green technologies and reduce carbon emissions. In the context of the renewable energy industry, carbon emissions trading can encourage investment in clean energy as companies seek to reduce carbon emissions and obtain licenses for future transactions.
Carbon pricing mechanisms, including carbon trading schemes, can play a key role in attracting private investment in the renewable energy sector, which is critical to meeting global climate goals, according to a World Bank report. The report states that “carbon pricing is an effective tool to guide capital for low-carbon investment, incentivize technological innovation, and help reduce emissions in the most cost-effective manner.” Carbon trading creates opportunities for companies to reduce carbon emissions by allowing them to sell unused allowances. This creates financial incentives, which in turn reduces the overall cost of abatement and promotes more efficient resource allocation.
The success of carbon trading schemes depends on a variety of factors, such as the initial allocation of emission allowances, the stability of carbon prices, and the effectiveness of monitoring and enforcement mechanisms. A study by the International Monetary Fund found that "well-designed carbon pricing systems can help governments generate revenue, encourage private sector investment in clean technologies, and help address climate change in a cost-effective manner." The study also noted that carbon pricing schemes It can help countries meet their climate goals, such as those set out in the Paris Agreement, and foster international cooperation on climate change.

summarize this => ompanies have long sensed the potential
value of investing in external start-ups. More
often than not, though, they just can’t seem to
get it right.
Recall the mad dash to invest in new ventures in the
late 1990s – and then the hasty retreat as the economy
turned. Nearly one-third of the companies actively in-
vesting corporate funds in start-ups in September 2000
had stopped making such investments 12 months later,
according to the research firm Venture Economics, and
during the same period, the amount of corporate money
invested in start-ups fell by 80%. This decline in invest-
ments was part of a historic pattern of advance and re-
treat, but the swings in recent years were even wider than
before: Quarterly corporate venture-capital investments
in start-ups rose from $468 million at the end of 1998 to
$6.2 billion at the beginning of 2000 and then tumbled
to $848 million in the third quarter of 2001. While private
VC investments also ebb and flow as the economy
changes, the shifts in corporate VC investments have been
particularly dramatic.
of Corporate
L
Venture
Capital
Making Sense
by Henry W. Chesbrough
Companies have, at best, a mixed
record funding start-ups. A new
framework, simple in design but
powerful in application, can help
identify the investments that will
yield a return that matters –
strategic growth.
Such inconsistent behavior certainly contributes to the
low regard with which many private venture capitalists
view in-house corporate VC operations. In their eyes, the
wild swings are further evidence that big companies have
neither the stomach nor the agility to manage invest-
ments in high-risk, fast-paced environments. They also
point to some high-profile missteps by individual compa-
nies to support this conclusion. Those missteps have,
in turn, tended to make some companies hesitant to
launch programs to invest in external start-ups, even in
good times.
A number of companies, however, have defied this
stereotype of the bumbling corporate behemoth and have
continued to make investments in new ventures. Even as
substantial numbers of corporate venture capitalists have
headed for the exits in the past year and a half, some big
companies – including Intel, Microsoft, and Qualcomm –
have publicly committed themselves to continued high
levels of investment. Others – such as Merck, Lilly, and
Millennium Pharmaceuticals – have actually come in the
door as others have left. What gives these optimists their
confidence? More generally, why have some companies’
forays into venture capital been successful, generating
significant growth for their own businesses?
To answer these questions, we need an orga-
nized way to think about corporate venture capi-
tal, a framework that can help a company decide
whether it should invest in a particular start-up
by first understanding what kind of benefit might
be realized from the investment. This article offers
such a framework, one that also suggests when –
that is, in what kind of economic climates – differ-
ent types of investment are likely to make sense.
But first, let’s briefly define corporate venture
capital. We use the term to describe the invest-
ment of corporate funds directly in external start-up
companies. Our definition excludes investments made
through an external fund managed by a third party, even
if the investment vehicle is funded by and specifically
designed to meet the objectives of a single investing com-
pany. It also excludes investments that fall under the
more general rubric of “corporate venturing” – for exam-
ple, the funding of new internal ventures that, while dis-
tinct from a company’s core business and granted some
organizational autonomy, remain legally part of the com-
pany. Our definition does include, however, investments
made in start-ups that a company has already spun off as
independent businesses.
Our framework helps explain why certain types of cor-
porate VC investments proliferate only when financial
returns are high, why other types persist in good times
and in bad, and why still others make little sense in any
phase of the business cycle. It can also help companies
evaluate their existing and potential VC investments and
determine when and how to use corporate VC as an in-
strument of strategic growth. The Dual Dimensions
of Corporate VC
A corporate VC investment is defined by two characteris-
tics: its objective and the degree to which the operations
of the investing company and the start-up are linked. Al-
though companies typically have a range of objectives for
their VC investments, this type of funding usually ad-
vances one of two fundamental goals. Some investments
are strategic: They are made primarily to increase the
sales and profits of the corporation’s own businesses. A
company making a strategic investment seeks to identify
and exploit synergies between itself and a new venture.
For example, Lucent Venture Partners, which invests the
telecommunications equipment maker’s funds in exter-
nal companies, makes investments in start-ups that are
focused on infrastructure or services for voice or data net-
works. Many of these companies have formal alliances
with Lucent to help sell Lucent’s equipment alongside
their own offerings. While Lucent would clearly like to
make money on its investments in these start-ups, it is
willing to accept low returns if its own businesses perform
better as a result of the investments.
The other investment objective is financial, wherein a
company is mainly looking for attractive returns. Here,
a corporation seeks to do as well as or better than private
VC investors, due to what it sees as its superior knowledge
of markets and technologies, its strong balance sheet, and
its ability to be a patient investor. In addition, a company’s
brand may signal the quality of the start-up to other in-
vestors and potential customers, ultimately returning
rewards to the original investor. For example, Dell Ven-
tures, Dell Computer’s in-house VC operation, has made
numerous Internet investments that it has expected to
earn attractive returns. While the company hopes that
the investments will help its own business grow, the main
march 2002 5
M a k i n g S e n s e o f Co r p o rat e Ve n t u re Ca p i ta l
Henry W. Chesbrough is an assistant professor of business
administration and the Class of 1961 Fellow at Harvard Busi-
ness School in Boston. He can be reached at hchesbrough@
hbs.edu.
Our framework can help companies evaluate
their existing and potential VC investments and
determine when and how to use corporate VC
as an instrument of strategic growth.
rationale for the investments has been the possibility of
high financial returns.
The second defining characteristic of corporate VC
investments is the degree to which companies in the in-
vestment portfolio are linked to the investing company’s
current operational capabilities – that is, its resources and
processes. For example, a start-up with strong links to the
investing company might make use of that company’s
manufacturing plants, distribution channels, technology,
or brand. It might adopt the investing company’s business
practices to build, sell, or
service its products.
Sometimes, of course, a
company’s own resources
and processes can become
liabilities rather than capa-
bilities, particularly when
it faces new markets or dis-
ruptive technologies.1 An
external venture may offer
the investing company an
opportunity to build new
and different capabilities – ones that could threaten the
viability of current corporate capabilities. Housing these
capabilities in a separate legal entity can insulate them
from internal efforts to undermine them. If the venture
and its processes fare well, the corporation can then eval-
uate whether and how to adapt its own processes to be
more like those of the start-up. In rare cases, the company
may even decide to acquire the venture.

Công ty OneIP có các "Cổ Đông Sáng Lập" cũng là "Cổ Đông Chủ Chốt". Có 2 Cổ Đông Sáng Lập và cả 2 đã góp vốn từ tháng 4 năm 2021.

Hiện công ty muốn đề xuất một người nữa tham gia vào làm "Cổ Đông Chủ Chốt". Cổ Đông Chủ Chốt này nếu tham gia sẽ tham gia từ tháng 4 năm 2023.

Trong yêu cầu này, một số từ được viết tắt như sau, nhưng trong kết quả được trả về thì không được viết tắt

- người được mời là "Thành Viên TIềm Năng", sau đây trong đoạn yêu cầu này viết tắt là TV
- Cổ Đông Chủ Chốt viết tắt là CC
- Cổ Đông Sáng Lập viết tắt là SL
- Doanh Thu viết tắt là DT
- Lợi Nhuận Kinh Doanh viết tắt là LNKD

Đề xuất có các điểm chính sau 

0. TV nếu đồng ý với thoả thuận này thì sẽ trở thành CC


1. Đầu tư : TV sẽ đầu tư 1 tỷ để đổi lấy 15% cổ phần của công ty

2. Thời gian nắm giữ : tất cả CC đều phải nắm giữ cổ phần trong 3 năm tính từ lúc góp vốn

3. Trong Thời gian nắm giữ, CC nào muốn ra đi có quyền yêu cầu công ty mua lại phần vốn góp của mình. 
- Giá công ty phải mua là mức vốn góp ban đầu, cộng với số tiền thêm tương đương lãi suất ngân hàng Vietcombank trong toàn bộ thời gian đã nắm giữ. Giá này gọi là "Giá bán chủ động". 
- Công ty phải thanh toán và mua lại, trừ trường hợp công ty không có "khả năng thanh toán" thì sẽ được khất việc thanh toán trong 12 tháng, nếu sau 12 tháng công ty vẫn không có khả năng thanh toán thì Công ty sẽ không phải mua lại. 
- "Khả năng thanh toán" là tổng lượng tiền công ty đang nắm giữ nhiều hơn là tổng của (1) số tiền phải bỏ ra để mua lại cổ phần và (2) Chi phí cố định của tháng gần nhất nhân 13 tháng.

4. Trong Thời gian nắm giữ, công ty có quyền mua lại toàn bộ cổ phần của bất kỳ CC nào và CC phải bán toàn bộ cổ phần mình có nếu công ty thực thi quyền này.
- Giá CC phải bán được tính theo định giá gần nhất giảm đi 30%, nhưng không được thấp hơn "Giá bán chủ động". 
- Giá này gọi là "Giá mua chủ động".

5. Ngoài ra TV còn được trông đợi sẽ giúp công ty đạt được các mục tiêu sau đây
- Cuối năm 2023 tạo ra doanh thu 50k$, và LNKD không âm
- Cuối năm 2024 tạo ra doanh thu 150k$, và LNKD lớn hơn 5% tổng doanh thu
- LNKD là tổng doanh thu trừ mọi chi phí liên quan đến kinh doanh
- Chi phi liên quan đến kinh doanh bao gồm các chi phí đi lại, ăn uống tiếp khách phục vụ cho việc tạo ra doanh thu, hoa hồng cho nhân viên và cho các đối tác bên ngoài, lương và các chi phí của các nhân viên kinh doanh

6. Ngay khi kết thúc năm 2023 hoặc 2024, nếu TV không giúp công ty đạt được những điều trên, thì công ty có quyền yêu cầu TV bán lại toàn bộ cổ phần của mình với Giá mua chủ động

Hãy viết một đề xuất chính thức để gửi cho TV, sử dụng văn phong chuẩn, của người làm kinh doanh, có các đề mục về định nghĩa. Sử dụng các sections có đánh số, bullet points, và format markdown để thể hiện rõ ràng từng phần. Thể hiện rõ TV sẽ được công ty phát hành thêm mới bao nhiêu cổ phần, và hãy viết các ví dụ về các kịch bản có thể xảy ra để minh hoạ các điểm số 3, số 4 và số 6, sử dụng các dữ kiện sau 
- Công ty sẽ gọi vốn thành công vào tháng 5 năm 2023 với lượng tiền gọi được là 7 tỷ đổi lấy 15%
- Hiện tại 2 cổ đông sáng lập đang nắm mỗi bên là 500 cổ phần

You are startup mentor.

I'm bootstrapping with a friend open source project, called Dekart. Dekart is similar to Kepler.gl and build on top of Kepler.gl. Main difference with Kepler.gl is that it Dekart implements backend to host created reports. Kepler.gl is client only. Dekart is integrated with BigQuery and Amazon Athena. Dekart interface allows writing SQL to extract and transform data for reports, similar to other BI tools like Redash. Once data fetched user can create maps via Kepler like UI.

Our personal goal is to grow open source project until business opportunity become evident to attract significant investment like series A. Alternatively is to bootstrap SaaS until it generates revenue which let us quit our day jobs.

Currently main competitors are:
* open source Kepler.gl
* Unfolded.ai created by authors of Kepler.gl and acquired by Foursquare
* CartoDB which pivots from SaaS for developers to SaaS for GIS professionals and Data Scientists  and competes with ArcGIS

We see two potential path for development:
* copy functionality of Unfolded.ai and CartoDB to Dekart open source projects which can deployed on premise by customers. Discover which niche can we occupy, for example we can optimize product for companies selling location datasets. Currently this companies are one of the main users, however their use case is not clear
* second option is to focus on original vision for Dekart: implement  analytic tool capable to fetch and visualize vast amount of datapoints. Our benchmark could be to support at least 1 million points for any visualization. This vision is inspired by our experience to analyze IoT and mobility data stored on company Lake House. Existing tools like Redash, Superset, Metabase are not capable to visualize over 100 thousands points and missing GIS visualizations. We could validate this strategy by publishing BI tools benchmarks and collecting users feedback.

Ask follow up questions and when have enough information, suggest 100 days plan.

Please help me to create a job description for a Transformation Manager for Comunidad Judía de Madrid. 
Key responsibilities
- Leading large-scale change in an organization
- Working with a variety of stakeholders and aligning different departments / teams
- Implementing new strategies, processes, systems and standards
- Orchestrating positive impact covering all transformation initiatives

Selected tasks
- Developing a case for each initiative and presenting it to senior leadership for approval
- Monitoring the progress of each initiative throughout its life cycle to ensure that deadlines are met and objectives are achieved
- Developing detailed implementation plans
- Coordinating with teams and other stakeholders
- Conducting training sessions
- Determining how to allocate resources to meet project goals / deadlines
- Working with external partners
- Analyzing data to determine where improvements can be made to increase efficiency or effectiveness of processes
- Establishing communication plans
